editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Sir Antony Love: OR, The Rambling Lady.
A COMEDY.
As it was Acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL by Their MAJESTIES Servants.
Written by THO. SOƲTHERNE.

q.l: Artis ſeverae ſi quis amat effectus,

div.p: LONDON, Printed for R. Wellington at the Lute in St. Paul's Church-yard. MDCXCVIII.

☞ Lately Publiſhed, The Hiſtory of Polybius the Mogalopolitan; containing a General Account of the Tranſactions of the whole World, but principally of the Roman People, during the Firſt and Second Punick Wars. Tranſlated by Sir Henry Sheers, and Mr. Dryden. In Three Volumes: The Third Volume never before Printed.

An Italian Voyage, or a compleat Journey thro' Italy. In Two Parts. With the Character of the People, and Deſcription of the chief Towns, Churches, Monaſteries, Tombs, Libraries, Palaces, Villa's, Gardens, Pictures, Statues and Antiquities; as alſo, of the Intereſt, Government, Riches, Force, &c. of all the Princes; with Inſtructions concerning Travel. By Richard Laſſell, Gent. The Second Edition. With large Additions, by a Modern Hand.

Familiar Letters: Written by John late Earl of Rocheſter, to the Honourable Henry Savile, Eſq and other Perſons of Quality: With Love-Letters, written by the late Ingenious Mr. Tho. Otway, Sir George Etheridge, and the late Duke of Buckingham. Price 5 s.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.

list.head: MEN.
list.item:
Wait-well, Sir Antony's Governour and …
fident.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Volante, the Abbe's Niece and Charge.

div.p: SCENE, Mompelier.

div.head: To my FRIEND Tho. Skipwith, Eſq
div.p: THere is that certain Argument of Poverty in Poetry, that its Offſpring muſt always be laid at ſomebodies Door; and indeed, the greatest Maſter of this Art, will ſcarce be able to ſupport the Iſſue of his Brain, upon the narrow Income of a ſingle Reputation.
From the very Start of my Deſign upon this Play, I had a Deſign upon you, like a rich Godfather, to eaſe the Pariſh of a Charge, and the Parent of a Care, in maintaining it.

You know the Original of Sir Antony, and therefore can beſt judge how the Copy is drawn; tho' it won't be to my Advantage to have 'em too narrowly compar'd; her Wit is indeed inimitable, not to be painted: Yet I must ſay, there's ſomething in my Draught of her, that carries a Reſemblance, and makes up a very tolerable Figure: And ſince I have this occaſion of mentioning Mrs. Montford, I am pleaſed, by way of Thanks, to do her that publick Juſtice in Print, which ſome of the beſt Judges of theſe Performances, have, in her Praiſe, already done her, in publick places; That they never ſaw any part more maſterly play'd: And as I made every Line for her, ſhe has mended every Word for me; and by a Gaiety and Air, particular to her Action, turn'd every thing into the Genius of the Character.
You have here Seven hundred Lines more in the Print, than was upon the Stage, which I cut out in the apprehenſion and dread of a long Play.

The Abbe's Character languiſhes in the Fifth Act for want of the Scene between him and Sir Antony, which I plainly ſaw before, but was contented to leave a Gap in the Action, and to loſe the advantage of Mr. Lee's Playing (which, tho' his Part, that place only gvve him an occaſion to ſhew) then run the venture of offending the Women; not that there is one indecent Expreſſion in it; but the over-fine Folk might run it into a deſign I never had in my head: my meaning was, to expoſe the Vice; and I thought it cou'd not be more contemptibly expos'd, than in the Perſon of a wanton Old Man, that muſt make ev'n the moſt faſhionable Pleaſure ridiculous.

I am gratefully ſenſible of the general good Nature of the Town to me, which you muſt give me leave to value my ſelf upon, ſince the Pride proceeds from an Opinion, that I have deſerv'd no otherwiſe from any Man. But I muſt make my boaſt (tho' with the moſt acknowledging reſpect) of the Favours for the Fair Sex (I may call 'em Favours, and I may boaſt of Ladies Favours, when there are ſo many concern'd) in ſo viſibly promoting my Intereſt, on thoſe Days chiefly (the Third, and the Sixth) when I had the tendereſt relation to the welfare of my Play. I won't from their Encouragement imagine I am the better Poet, but I will for the future, endeavour not to give 'em cauſe of repenting ſo ſeaſonable a piece of good Nature; and if I can't give 'em a good Comedy, I won't give 'em a very bad one: This has had its Fate, and a very favourable one. And I cannot but have the better eſteem of it, for bringing ſo many of my Well-wiſhers together.
So far for Prefacing.

Now, Sir, as to my Dedication: I fear my Credit in this place, is as little worth, as in Lumbard-ſtreet; you may take up Money upon it, as ſoon as a Reputation: But the Bleſſing of the Fortune lies in having as little need of your Friend's Purſe in the City, as your Friend's Praiſe in Coven-Garden: They who know you, will take you upon your own Word; and they who don't, will hardly upon mine. However, this I muſt ſay, if there be a quickneſs in the Dialogue, and Converſation of this Comedy, I owe it in a great meaſure to my familiarity with you; which in the freedom of ſeveral Years, has giv'n me a thouſand occaſions of Envy and Admiration; and at laſt perſwaded me to an Imitation of what I have heard with ſo much pleaſure and pain. I wou'd not flatter a Friend: But I have often thought, and ſometimes told you, That were it as much in your inclination, as 'tis in your power, to write Comedy, no Man cou'd better ſucceed in't, becauſe no Man can be more naturally deſign'd for the Ʋndertaking. I don't pretend to add any thing to the Character of a Man ſo very well known: If I have a deſign, behind the pleaſing my ſelf, in Dedicating this Play to you, 'tis to ſecure the Eſteem of being thought your Friend: As I have the Title, I deſire to continue the Thing; being very much

div.head: Sir Antony Love: OR, The Rambling Lady.

div.stage: Enter Sir Antony Love, and Wait-well following him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: WELL, Governour, I think I have Atchiev'd, under thy Conduct, as conſiderable a Character in as ſhort a time—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Nay, you come on amain.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And, though I ſay it, have done as much—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And suffer'd as much.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: For the Credit of my Country men, and the Reputation of a Whoremaſter, as the erran'ſt Rake-hell of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: You're a pretty Proficient indeed, and ſo perfectly act the Cavalier, that cou'd you put on our Sex with your Breeches, o' my Conſcience, you wou'd carry all the Women before you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And drive all the Men before me; I am for Univerſal Empire, and wou'd not be ſtinted to one Province; I wou'd be fear'd, as well as lov'd:
sp.l: As famous for my Action with the Men,
As for my Paſſion for the Women.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: You're in the way to't; you change your Men as often as you do your Women; and have every day a new Miſtreſs, and a new Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why, 'tis only the Faſhion of the World, that gives your Sex a better Title than we have, to the wearing a Sword; my conſtant Exerciſe with my Fencing Maſter, and Converſation among Men, who make little of the matter, have at laſt not only made me adroit, but deſpiſe the Danger of a Quarrel too.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: A Lady-like Reputation, truly. But how prepoſterouſly Fortune places her Favours, when no body is the better for 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why how now, Governour?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: She ſeldom gives a Man an Eſtate, who has either the Conſcience or Youth to enjoy it—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But he may leave it to one who has.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: An honeſt Man might be thankful for half your Fortune with the Women. But what pleaſure can you find in following 'em?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: The ſame that ſome of the Men find.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: You can't enjoy 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But I may make 'em ready for thoſe who can.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Are there ſuch Sports-men?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Very many, who beat about more for Company, than the pleaſure of the Sport; and if they do ſtart any thing, are better pleas'd with the accidents of the Chaſe, the Hedges, and Ditches, than the cloſe Purſuit of the Game; and theſe are ſure never to come into the Quarry.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: This is ſo like you now: Why Love ſhou'd be your buſineſs; and you make a buſineſs of your Love: You are young and handſome in Petticoats; yet are contented to part with the Pleaſures of your own Sex, to ramble into the Troubles of ours. In my Opinion, you might be better employ'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I do it to be better employ'd; to recommend me to Valentine, for whoſe dear ſake I firſt engag'd in the Adventure; robb'd my Keeper, that nauſeous Fool Golding, of Five hundred Pounds, and under thy Diſcretion, came a Collonelling after him here into France.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Why do you loſe time then? Why don't you tell him ſo?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Thou wou'dſt have had me, with the true Conduct of an Engliſh Miſtreſs, upon the firſt inclination, cloy'd him with my Perſon, without any aſſurance of his reliſhing me; enough to raiſe his Appetite to a ſecond taſte: No, now I am ſure he likes me; and likes me ſo well in a Man, he'll love me in a Woman; and let him make the Diſcovery if he dares.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Let me 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To the Lodgings you ſhall; thoſe I ſaw, and lik't; they're Private, and Convenient, make 'em ready; I'll tell thee all anon— And do you hear— my Female Wardrobe too muſt be produc'd, my Womans Equipage— [Wait-well going.] For as the Conduct of Affairs now goes, I'm beſt diſguis'd in my own Sex, and Cloaths. Hey, I had forgot; bring me the Fifty Pieces I ſpoke of, the Five hundred are in good Health yet, Governour.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: But ſicken at that ſound.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Valentine and Ilford are diſappointed of their Bills, and in ſpite of their good Eſtates want Money; now, tho' I lend upon the old conſideration of borrowing a greater Sum, Fifty Pieces are convenient.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And will be welcome to 'em at this time—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Moſt certainly; and take this along with you, Governour; You muſt make your Converſation neceſſary ſometimes, as well as agreeable, to preſerve a Friendſhip with an Engliſh-man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How's this, Sir Antony? under the Diſcipline of your Governour, and his Wiſdom, this Morning?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Like a good Chriſtian, Valentine, clearing old Accounts, that I may begin a new Score, with a better Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Confeſſing, and repenting paſt Enormities—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: About the pitch of thy Piety, Ilford, repenting only, becauſe they are paſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: So far you may repent with Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p:
Nay, I Confeſs my ſelf a Child of this World; for at this moment
I have a Hint from my Conſtitution, that tells me the pleaſure of thy Example—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thou art above Example, or Imitation—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Will go near to overthrow the Wiſdom of his Precepts; the Morality of thy Beard, Governour—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: But, Sir, it wou'd be well.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: It wou'd be better, Sir, thou pitiful Preacher, wou'dſt thou but follow thy Pimping; 'tis a better Trade, and becomes thy Diſcretion as well: You'll find me hereabouts—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You have Compounded for Whoring then, Sir Antony?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Any thing but Fighting; he has ſwing'd me away for my Quarrel yeſterday i'th' Tennis-Court.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You deſerv'd to be ſwing'd for't—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I ſhou'd chide you too, though 'twas upon my account.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To run a Gentleman thro' the Arm, for not witneſſing all you ſaid in Commendation of Valentine—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: When he was not ſo much as acquainted with my Perſon—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Was—

sp.speaker: Sir. Ant.
sp.p: Something more bold than welcome, I grant you; but I had not fought a great while, my hand was in, and I was puſhing at Reputation. For, I Gad, I look upon Courage to proceed more from Habit and Practice, than any Virtue of the Mind.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How 〈◊〉
Sir Anthony
〈…〉 ſomething in Family 〈◊〉 —

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Wooden Legs, in a great many, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Courage often runs in a Blood—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: They ſay ſo of the Pox, indeed. The Sins of the Fathers may run in the Blood ſometimes, and viſit the third and fourth Generation: But their Virtues dye with the Men. And if the Example, and Cuſtom of the World (ſupported by good eating and drinking) had not infus'd a nobler Spirit into the Blood, than any deriv'd from the Father; moſt Men had continu'd like thoſe, who ſtay with their Fathers; Elder Brothers all; and had never offer'd at an Intrigue, above a red Petticoat; or a Quarrel, above a Rubber at Cuffs.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: 'Tis ſenſibly extravagant, and wild!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Inimitably new! But how do you to avoid Drinking?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why that avoids me, thanks to the Cuſtom of the Countrey, and the better Diverſions of this Place; not but I can arrive at a Bottle too.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: If you were in London—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There I grant you— Where the young Fellows begin the Reputation of their Humour and Wit in a Pint Glaſs, carrying 'em, without intermiſſion of ſenſe or jeſt, to the end of the third Bottle; and then thro' the publick places, and folly of the Town.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: There you wou'd be at a loſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I ſhou'd indeed; where they go to Taverns, to ſwallow a Drunkenneſs; and then to a Play, to talk over their Liquor.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I thought that folly fell off with their Fathers—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Entertainment of it did indeed.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Who, as they began it in their Frolick, ſupported it in their Wit.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And ſince the Sons are ſo plainly diſinherited of the Senſe, they have no Title to the Sins of their Fathers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Unleſs they kept 'em more in Countenance.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Yet they would do ſomething, like their Fathers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As an ignorant Player in England, whom I ſaw undertaking to Copy a Maſter Actor of his time; began at his Infirmity in his Feet; and growing famous for the imitation of his Gout, he cou'd walk like him, when he cou'd do nothing elſe like him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: The Gout, and the Pox take him for't—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And all thoſe, I ſay, who, only from their Opinion of themſelves, are encourag'd to meddle in other Men's matters, without ever bringing any thing about of their own.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Aye, thoſe medling Fools, Ilford! who are in all places, yet ever out of their way—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And not only out of their own way, but always in other Mens—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And ſtill as ridiculous as a Fellow of thy Severity and Reſerve wou'd be in the fantaſtical Figure of a Lover.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Whoever has the Woman; you have your Wit, Sir Antony—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: They go together, Sir— You'll find it ſo.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A 〈…〉 about him!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: One of that travelling Tribe, without their Circumciſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Of Chriſtian Appellation, a Pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſenſeleſs Conſtitution of Men!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Who make themſelves Mad, to make the reſt of the World Fools, by finding a Faith for all their Fopperies.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How can they paſs upon the World?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: As other Conſtitutions, and Orders of Men as ſenſeleſs, paſs; that are founded too in as much Cozenage and Roguery as this can be.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You are an Enemy of Forms, Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, the Virtue of the Habit often covers the Vices of the Man: There's Field enough in England to find this in, without the Abby-lands, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Weeds are the general growth of every Soil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How many Fools in the State, and Atheiſts in the Church, carry themſelves currant thro' their Congregations and Clients, to great Emyloyments; and, being arm'd only with the Authority and Countenance of their Cloathing, ſecure themſelves from the diſcovery and ſenſure of the Court and Town?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Theſe are Diſguiſes, I grant you, worth a ſenſible Man's putting on; but a Pilgrim's Habit is as ridiculous as his Pretence; and I wou'd no more wear a Fools Coat, to be thought devout; than be devout for the ſake of the Livery.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Fools are the Guts of all Churches, and make the Bulk of every Opinion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hang him, let him paſs; ſpare him for the ſake of the Church, and ſpare the Church for the ſake of our Abbe.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Who is, indeed, a moſt conſiderable Pillar of it, to his own profit, and our pleaſurable living in this Town.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He is a very Pope in Mompelier, the Head here—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And a fit Head he is for ſuch ſinful Members as we are.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: We Members! You are a Proteſtant, Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You may be ſurly enough to tell 'em you are one; but I am always of the Religion of the Government I am in—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And of the Women you converſe with, Knight.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And when I can't convince 'em, I conform.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A very civil Character of a faſhionable Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Of a ſenſible Man, I think: Why muſt your Capacity be the Meaſure of another Man's Underſtanding? And all Men be in the wrong, who don't dance i'th' Circle of your Thoughts?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Every Man a Villain, or a Fool, who does not fall into your Notion of things?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No Opinion ever ſprung out of an Univerſal Conſent; Truth can no more be comprehended, than Beauty: We have our ſeveral Reaſons for the one, and Fancies for the other. And as Beauty has not the ſame influence upon all Complexions; ſo Reaſon has not the ſame Force upon all Underſtandings: We embrace what pleaſes us in both, ſecure our ſelves in a probability, and gueſs out the reſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Ilford is one of thoſe Fellows, whom if you divide from in one thing, will never cloſe with you in any. Tho the Abbe and you do differ about the way to Heav'n, you may go to the Devil together, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: However wide we may be from his Opinion of t'other World, I'm ſure he joyns with us in our Opinion of this.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: For my part, I regard the Man, not his Religion; and if he does my Buſineſs in this World, let him do his own in the next.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen, I have as honourable an Opinion of the Abbe, as you can have: I know there's nothing to be done without him—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That the Converſation of the beſt Families in Mompelier runs thro' his Reformation—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: That ſome of our Fortunes—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: All our Fortunes—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Yours particularly with Floreante, at preſent depending upon his Favour, againſt the Authority of her Father—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And the Quality of my Rival, Count Verole.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: No Dancings, no Balls, no Maſquerades, in a ſweet Circle of Society, as it has been, from one Good Houſe to another, without his Introduction and Gravity to qualifie the Scandal.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Subſtantial Reaſons for our Reſpect.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Weighty Motives all for our Attendance.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Are they ſo, Sir? No more of your Proteſtant then, if you wou'd not be damn'd for a Heretick, by the Women in a Catholick Countrey.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: We ſhou'd ha' been at our Patron's Levy, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: He'll bate us us the Ceremony: You're going to viſit him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You muſt along with us.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are his Favourite; we are no body without you—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The ſupport of our intereſt with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Buſineſs, Buſineſs, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pox o' your Buſineſs—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: 'Twill end in that—prithee let him go; a Whore I warrant you— Whore; more proſtituted too, to Knaves and Fools: Yet my grave Friend, you'll have a ſhare in both, or I miſtake your Nature.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are anſwer'd.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Indeed my little Friend is ſo far right, Money, and Whore, make one anothers uſe; either is dull alone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This Pilgrim here again!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: He follows us; what wou'd he have?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Your Charity, good Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Prithee leave us; there's Charity in my Advice to thee, not to loſe thy labour; beſides, we are Engliſh-men; and never think of the Poor out of our own Pariſh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nor there neither, but according to Law, and when we cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Charity is a Free-will-Offering, and we part with nothing we can keep, I aſſure you—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not ſo much as our ſins.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Eſpecially at this time—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Unleſs it be to live upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Alas! what pity 'tis, that Gentlemen ſo much in debt—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That we ſhall never pay—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: To Heaven—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And other Creditors.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Of Youth ſo ſweet, of Form ſo excellent—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You or me, Ilford? Who does he mean?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: So finiſh'd, by the great Creator's Hand, I worſhip him in thee.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: As thou do'ſt the King's Picture in his Coyn—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: In hopes of getting by it.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: You are ſo faſhion'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: For a Sinner.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: And by Natures Hand deſign'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A Whoremaſter.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: You can't want—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Women? No, Pilgrim, I ſhan't want 'em, in thy Acquaintance, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: You can't want Grace, the Beauty of the Soul, the Accompliſhment of Virtue to the work: You can't wan't Chairty; for Charity is call'd our Gratitude to Heav'n—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You call it ſo.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: You would not be Ungrateful?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I wou'd not be a Fool, nor imagine ſuch an Aſs as thou art cou'd ever be Commiſſion'd, a' God's Name, to collect the Revenues of this World—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nor to Convert (thoſe Deodands of Devotion) the publick Charitable Endowments of Bigotted, or Dying Fools, to the private Luxury of your own Lazy Tribe.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: We build no Churches, Pilgrim, nor found Hoſpitals, but in our own Countrey; nor there neither, but to Father our own Baſtards.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Your Mendicant Women-Saints, we allow off indeed: All our Charity runs thro' their Devotion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Soft little Hands become an Offering, and thoſe we often fill.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Are you ſo loſt.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To all that thou can'ſt ſay.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Thy Godlineſs may Convert others, tho' it does nothing upon us.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Pimp for us.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I will Pray for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Do't in a Corner alone then, [Thruſts him out.] Be as Godly as thou wou't by thy ſelf; and leave us to our Devotions.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I may joyn with you in yours, before I have done; the Abbe won't fail me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I have my hands full, Gentlemen; but my Trade is ſettled, my Correſpondence eaſie, my Factors employ'd, and my Returns will be quick.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray make 'em ſo; and come as ſoon as you can to us.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I ſail with every wind, in the Teeth of Fortune ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Have a care of being bit, Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I 〈…〉 older Sinner. Valentine I warrant you—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You may venture him: He has nothing to loſe, that I know of, but his Youth; and that wonnot long ſupport the expence of the life he leads.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: He loſes no time, indeed.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But miſemploys a great deal, in my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Youth will have its Sallies.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The Sallies of his Youth will ſooner lead him to Repentance and the Pox, than to his Mannor of Love-dale, as he calls it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: His Manſion-houſe in Gloceſterſhire.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: His Caſtle in the Air, which no Man ever heard of, till he was pleas'd to fancy, and Chriſten it, for the Seat of his Family.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then you don't believe him a Barronet, of twelve hundred pounds a year, under Age, and upon an Allowance for his Travel, from his Guardians?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I believe he may have been ſome Court Page, ſpoil'd firſt by the Confidance of his Lady, in knowing her Secrets; then coming early into the iniquity of the Town, by the merit of his Perſon, and impudence, has ſince made a faſhionable Livelihood, out of Women and Fools.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I don't know who he is, or wat he has: If he be no Knight, he's a pretty Fellow, and that's better: And if he has not Twelve Hundred Pounds a Year, he deſerves it, and does not want it: Which is more than you can ſay of moſt of your Knights, that have that Eſtate, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay, that I grant you too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: He lives as like a Gentleman, has all things as well about him; is as much reſpected by the Men, and better receiv'd by the Women, than any of us.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He's a pretty Womans Man indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And a merry Man's Man too, Sir; for you muſt own, he has a great deal of Wit.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Pretty good Natural Parts, I confeſs; but a Fool has the keeping 'em, no Judgment in the World; and what he ſays, comes as much by chance—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As Epicurus's World did; Perfect, and Uniform, without a Deſign.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He flies too much at random to pleaſe any Man of Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: There is indeed the Quarrel of Twelve Years difference, between thy Diſcretion, and his Wit. He may live up to thy Diſcretion, George, but we ſhall neither of us arrive at his Wit.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How long will his Wit ſupport him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That muſt be his Care, and not our Buſineſs: I never examine any man's Pockets, that is not troubleſome to mine.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: If he be not troubleſome, his Neceſſities may throw him upon ſome ſcandalous Action—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That may require thy Bailing him?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: That may reflect upon us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O! thou wer't always tender of thy Reputation, when thou wer't to pay for the Scandal, I'll ſay that for thee, Ilford: But if want of Money be a Crime; Heav'n help the guilty: We are diſappointed of our Bills at preſent too.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But we have Letters of Credit, and may uſe 'em upon occaſion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And 〈…〉 , which he may uſe too, upon Occaſion; for I am ſo far from apprehending he may, that I am reſolv'd he ſhall want nothing I can oblige him in, Pocket or Perſon.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O! Sir, you need not doubt his giving you an opportunity of ſhewing your Gallantry in that part of your Friendſhip; he'll borrow Money of you, warrant you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And he ſhall have it, tho' I borrow it for him. But, Sir, you had not always this ſlight Opinion of Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I did not always know him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nor he the Abbe's Niece.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I found him out but lately.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: For your Rival.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: His Vanity, Extravagance, and general Pretenſion to Women, are intolerable—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Eſpecially when the gayety of that Humour is likely to get the better of your formality, in Volante's eſteem: He is your Rival.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: My Rival!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I don't wonder, you don't like him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He's a general Undertaker, indeed; and in that part of his Converſation, is as impertinent to the Women, as in other things he is troubleſome to the Men: So I think it wou'd be our common good Fortune to get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am not of your mind: And here he comes to convince you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Juſt as I left you! You ſcorn to ſtir an inch out of your quality, to put your ſelves in the way of Fortune, tho' you know her to be blind.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You meet her at every turn, Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: She muſt come home to you to be welcome.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: When do you bring her home?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But you may be ſullen, and ſour, domineer, threaten your Stewards, and talk loud at a Diſappointment; you are in poſſeſſion, Gentlemen:
My Guardians won't be ſo ſerv'd: My Governour teaches me to provide againſt Accidents: What I want of my Age, I muſt ſupply with my Diligence.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And have your labour for your pains.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I can take pains, Sir, and the profit of my pains, Sir; Fifty pieces in a Morning, Sir, the price of my pains, and give the Lady a penniworth into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How! Fifty Pieces?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: From a Woman, Sir Antony?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, a trifle.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your Miſtreſs pays like a Widow—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That had loſt her Youth upon a Husband, and the hopes of a Joynture—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And juſt deliver'd, wou'd redeem the folly of the paſt, by the enjoyment of what's to come—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: In a ſober Reſolution, of making the price of her pennance, the purchaſe of her pleaſure—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: By refunding upon a young Fellow, what ſhe had wheadl'd from an old one.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I warrant her old, and ugly, by her Penſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: She's young enough to be a Maid, handſome enough to be a Miſtreſs, cunning enough to be a Wife, and rich enough to be a Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Faith, ſhe comes down—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Deeper than I can, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: She pays well, I'll ſay that for her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And is well— I'll ſay that for her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And does every thing well.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You wou'd ſay that for her, Valentine? And ſhe does every thing well; that way ſhe is a Widow, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Take us into your Aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: We are Friends, and will ſtand by you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: We are out of Employment that way—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And wou'd Journey-work under you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Any thing to be wicked, Gentlemen: But, Ilford, thou art honourably in Love, and haſt it too much in thy head, to have it any where elſe. Beſides, ſhe's ſo much of my humour, ſhe'll never reliſh thine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She muſt not go out of our Family.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: She's handſome and convenient; as able to anſwer all our wants, as all we are to ſatisfie the importunity of hers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well; I am ſatisfy'd, I am her Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Or any Woman's Man, who wants to be ſatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She muſt like me, for being of her Opinion, in liking thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That indeed may do ſomething, and time may bring it about: In ſhort, this is the Engliſh Lady you have heard me ſpeak of: I allow her the favour of my Perſon; and ſhe allows me the freedom of her Purſe: And I am glad I command it ſo luckily, to anſwer the Occaſions of my Friends.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You can command nothing we can have occaſion for.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By your Pardon, Sir, you may be too proud to be oblig'd; but I have occaſion for the Money and Woman too, ſo as you were ſaying, Sir Antony—

div.stage: Enter a Servant, Ilford goes to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why, I ſtill ſay a true bred Engliſh-man is ever out of humour when he's out of Pocket: He knows no more how to want Money, than how to borrow it—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And when he does, is as ſurly in borrowing, as others are in lending Money.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis almoſt as dangerous too, to offer him Money, as to lend Money to another Man: For he is as likely, out of a want of Senſe, to ſuffer your Courteſie; as a Stranger, out of a want of Honeſty, never to return it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That way, indeed, our Countrymen take care, never to think themſelves oblig'd: We can be ungrateful—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And cheat our Benefactors of their good Offices, by an Ingratitude, almoſt natural to us; and that makes a tolerable amends for our want of the more 〈◊〉 Villanies of warmer Countries.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But the Lady, Sir Antony—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: More of the Lady at leiſure; in the mean time, here are Fifty Pieces of hers, too keep up your Fancy: If your Occaſions require a greater Sum— ſhe ſhall ſupply you—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I'll ſupply her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Upon your Bond, for the payment of the whole to her in England—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A Blank Bond, becauſe ſhe wou'd not be known here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: With all my Heart, but won't ſhe take a Gentleman's Word?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: O yes, when ſhe has his Bond for the performance. When our ſurly Friend is Civil enough to be oblig'd, I have a Twin-Purſe at his Service too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are very much out of his Favour of late.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: So I find: What's the Matter with the Fool?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How have you diſoblig'd him?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But he's in Love, and conſequently an Aſs.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I believe Jealous of you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Faith I'll give him Cauſe. Volante is as fit for my purpoſe of Tormenting him that way, as I could wiſh. Shall we to the Abbe, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Golding! An Engliſh-Man?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: So his Servants tell me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Juſt come to Town, ſay'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He has not peep'd abroad, ſince his coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Do you know any ſuch Gentleman, Valentine?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I did; a conſiderable Coxcomb of that Name, in England; a Knight, Sir Gentle Golding. Sir Antony, you may have known him too.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I have heard of him. If this ſhou'd prove my Coxcomb Governour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But Damn him, he has not Courage enough to croſs the Channel.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I know he is in France, I heard of him at Paris.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, it muſt be the Man—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Whom we muſt manage then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why do'ſt think ſo?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Your Deſcription is ſo like him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, haſt thou found him out—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: For his Father's Son, and his Mother's Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And our Fool, Gentlemen: If he be a Fool, I'll have my Snack of him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There's enough for you all, without wronging the Family, as he will quickly convince you. He knows you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then 'tis the very Fool.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: And deſigns to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: At his Peril be't: I owe him a Revenge, for Lucia's ſake.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Is this the Spark?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That bought her of her Aunt—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Now for my Character.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: When ſhe was yet too young, to Judge between the Fortune and the Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That's ſome Excuſe however.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A little time ſhew'd her, her ſenſeleſs Bargain.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: So I hear.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Which, ſhe repenting, gave you the cheaper Penniworth of her Perſon: Then was the time—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That I was in France; out of the reach of any other Pleaſure, had ſhe deſign'd me any, than the bare News, that ſhe had found him out, loath'd, and abhorr'd him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Loathing and Abhorring, are Tokens of Mortification indeed: But Pennance is not enough for ſuch a Fault; 'tis generally as ſhort liv'd, as the Sin that begot it. What marks of Amendment has ſhe ſince given?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: What marks of Amendment wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I know nothing of her Amendment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Wou'd you have her Snivle, like a Girl; more afraid of her Mother, than the Sin; and cry, forgive me this one ſlip, I'll do ſo no more—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Repent upon the firſt Intrigue—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Turn Honeſt, and diſparage the Pleaſure, by leaving the Trade.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: By no means, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Wou'd you have her already fall off—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Become a Civil Perſon—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And take up—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: With ſome body that better deſerves her; that way I wou'd have her a Civil Perſon, and fall off from her Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Indeed a Woman never repents of a Fool ſo heartily, as in the Arms of a Man of Senſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How Fortune has diſpos'd of her, I know not; but I lik'd her once ſo
well, I wou'd have her ſtill preſerve my good Opinion of her Conduct: If ſhe has manag'd her Monſter, as he deſerv'd, ſhe has made Money and Mirth of him; and me ſome Amends for the loſs of her, by mending her Condition.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If that will preſerve your good Opinion of her, ſhe will continue it: For I hear ſhe has us'd him as ill, as you cou'd deſire from your Revenge; or the Town expect from their Hopes of a Libel.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then I honour her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: She has robb'd him of Five Hundred Pounds, run away from him; and ſo expos'd him, that he has been the common Rhyming Theam, the Hackney Pegaſus for the Puny Poets to ſet out upon, in their vaſt Ambition, of arriving at a Lampoon.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And that perhaps has ſent him into France.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, I will have her Knighted.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Of what Order? A Knight Errant, or an Errant Knight?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A Knight Errant, of thy Order, ſhe muſt be.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: That ſhe is already.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And thee a Right Honourable, for thy News.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You may depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If ever I light on her, I'll thank her for this Juſtice to us all.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Golding may tell us more of her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So he may, you, Sir, wait at our Lodgings for him,
And direct him to the Abbe's, if he comes:
We'll laugh at him, if we do nothing more.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But he and I muſt clear another ſcore.

div.head: SCENE I. A Garden.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: BRother, you may forget your ſelf, and your Rank, as much as you pleaſe, in our Niece Volante: I have nothing to do with her, but to wiſh her well.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: 'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: You are her Guardian: Her Perſon, her Fortune, and her Conduct are in your Care.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I'll take Care of 'em.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: You muſt anſwer for 'em.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I will anſwer for 'em.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: But my Daughters are under my Government; and whilſt they are, they muſt, nay ſhall do nothing to diſhonour me.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: They will do nothing to diſhonour you.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I'll put it out of their Power, had they a mind to't.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: They ha' no ſuch Mind.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: That's more than I can tell, from the Liberties you give theſe Engliſh-men in our Family—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: They are Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I apprehend a Danger, tho' you won't.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Pugh, pugh, there is no danger.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I'll prevent it, if there were.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: All Men of Fortune, in their Countrey.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: They are not Men of Quality. Wou'd Count Verola were come.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Don't do ſo raſh a thing.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I'll rid my ſelf of all my fears at once; diſpoſe my youngeſt Daughter in a Nunnery, and inſtantly marry Floriante—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: To make her more miſerable.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Suitable to her Birth.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: To a Fool, the worſt of Fools; a Singular, Opinionated, Obſtinate, Crooked-temper'd, Jealous-pated Fool.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: If he were ſo, that Fool's a Count; and the Count makes amends for the Fool.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Then he is welcome— [Count Verole enters to 'em.] Virtue created firſt Nobility; but in our honourable Ignorance Nobility makes Virtue.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What ſays the Abbe?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Sir, you are moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I ſhall be glad to find it from the Man I ſo much honour—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: For his Title,
That's all this Fellow thinks worth honouring.
Hang 'em, they make me Grave—
But that a Brother of my Blood ſhou'd chuſe a Coxcomb out—
But if my Brother prove a Coxcomb too,
That Wonder's over—
Then 'tis their mutual intereſt to joyn;
Each likes the other to excuſe himſelf.
sp.stage: Sir Ant. Val. and Ilford enter to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Ah, Monſieur L'Abbe.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You have prevented us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: We were going to viſit you.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: In Nomine Domine, Amen.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The Abbe making his Will!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Amen to our Abbe's Devotions.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: You fall as naturally as a Pariſh-Clerk, into the cloſe of a Prayer.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I love to bring things to a good end.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Nay I have done; my Devotion won't tire your Attention.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You are like the Prelate, that being dignify'd for long Prayers, hated them ever after.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Long Prayers are for poor Prieſts that want Preferment, Men of Quality riſe without 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: In Men of your Rank they are Phariſaical, and always to carry on a Deſign.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I neither have a Faith in them nor their Followers; and therefore I ſeldom or never pray at all.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How! never Pray at all?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: The Church and I are agreed upon the Bargain; and few words are beſt, when the Parties are of a mind.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But the Church may better your Bargain.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I am mortify'd to the Dignities and Deſigns of the Church; have laid aſide the Pomp and Pride of my Profeſſion, I am contented to ſit down in a Sine-Cure; and, with the poor pittance of 2000 Piſtols a year, make the moſt of a good Conſcience and good Company.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A good Conſcience is good Company indeed.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I mean, Sir, I'll make a Conſcience of good Company—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Make the beſt of the Bleſſing, and enjoy it as long as you can.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Ah! my little Knight underſtands me, tho' you won't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You'll anger him—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: He jumps into the Point with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And into the Company too, dear Abbe; I muſt make one.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Make one, thou mak'ſt all; thou'rt all in all; the whole Company thy ſelf; thou art every thing with every body; a Man among the Women, and a Woman among the Men.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How Abbe! Sir Antony a Woman?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: One might indeed miſtake him, by his Face.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He wou'd miſtake him, I believe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Somewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: But there's no faith in Faces; the Women have found him out, and won't truſt him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the Women Abbe, the Ladies—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: As mad as ever they were, my Nieces you mean!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I long to be among 'em.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Nay, they long too, if that wou'd do 'em any good. And think it long.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I have not ſpoke to a Woman this half hour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: We are all idle without you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sin has been as ſilent among us.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: As in the firſt Seſſion of a Parliament, in fear of a Reformation.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Ah! very well, I faith, my little Man. But no, no Reformation, I warrant you; matters ſhall not be much mended by my Management; Sin muſt ſometimes get the better of the Saint.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Or the Devil may ſtill wear black, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Let him wear what he will: We have had him in our Family this Morning.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: My Brother has diſcover'd ſomething between you, and his Eldeſt Daughter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That's unlucky.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Which to prevent, he deſigns to Marry her inſtantly to Count Verole.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: That's bad indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What is there to be done?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Nothing that I know of.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: What's to be done? Any thing's to be done?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What if I run away with her?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Or if I cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Or Bed-rid him with a beating.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If none of theſe will do, let him Marry her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I muſt ſay with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If you can't make her your Wife, make him your Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ah! if I durſt but hope that way.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Hope, you muſt hope Man, and you muſt dare Man, if you wou'd do any thing with the Women.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Can you encourage me?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why, Faith, what-ever her Father deſigns, ſhes does not deſign to Marry him: And Diſobedience may make way for other Sins.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I know ſhe hates him.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: And I know ſhe likes you. And if I have any Authority from the Church—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Which is not to be diſputed.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Or any Intereſt from my Eſtate—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Which muſt be conſiderable—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Not to be oppos'd—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: And which muſt furniſh the better part of her Fortune, he ſha'nt have her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That's gaining time at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He's naturally jealous.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And has ſettled that Nature by a Spaniſh Education, they ſay.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: He was bred in Spain indeed.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A miſerable Woman ſhe muſt be then.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I wou'd not have a Niece of mine marry'd into a Family, or Nation, where, if ſhe diſlike her own Man, ſhe can have no body elſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Our Women are the happy Women, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why, indeed your Engliſh-men are the fitteſt Men for Husbands in the World! Wou'd all my Female Relations were married into your Countrey!

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Wou'd they thought as well of us, as you do.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: There is a Lady quarrels at her Condition, or likes another Man better than her Husband; which ſometimes may happen, you know.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Such things have happen'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: There they ſay Cuckoldom is in faſhion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Nay, more than in faſhion, Sir, 'tis according to Law; Cuckoldom is the Liberty, and a ſeperate Maintenance, the Property of the Freeborn Women of England.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: We give our Women fair play for't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And ſcorn any Tie upon 'em, more than their Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why, what wou'd a Lady ask more in Marriage? I'll maintain it, ſuch a Priviledge is better than her Dower; and in a prudent Woman's thoughts, muſt take place of any other Conſideration.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: 'Tis as much before a Dower in Profit too, as in time; for a Husband may cheat a Wife of her Dower.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Or wear out her Title by out-living her; and then ſhe is bob'd of her Reverſion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Or leave her ſo old, ſhe may be paſt having any good from it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Unleſs ſhe lays it out in redeeming ſome younger Brother—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: That had ſpent his Annuity in a Lord's Company—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Or in following a Common Whore—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Or in following as Common a Miſtreſs, the Court.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And being reduc'd to the laſt Fifty, had ventur'd it prudently on a Birth-day Coat, and the Hopes of an Employment.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: One, who in ſpight of having been once undone, will have no more profit from his Experience, than to fall into the ſame folly agen, with the ſame occaſion.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Then hang him for a Fool, enough of him— I am convinc'd with what you ſay, Gentlemen: And you ſhall have my Niece, you have her Conſent, and my Conſent, and Sir Antony's good Word; which I promiſe you, goes a great way with the Women.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your Niece Volante is her Confident.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I'll make her your Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I'll ſecure her for you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why you ſecure her?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: For ſuch a favour, Sir, I think I may.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Your Intereſt is mighty.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: So far I can engage her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You engage her!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Nay, oblige her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Her Friendſhip may oblige her, but not you.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Pray don't quarrel about obliging her; Volante is my Favourite, ſhe ſhall pleaſe her ſelf, and I believe wou'd pleaſe Sir Antony —Gentlemen, you are three, and my Nieces are three; I wo'nt meddle in your Choice; agree among your ſelves; win 'em, and wear 'em; I had rather you ſhou'd have 'em, than my Brother diſpoſe of 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, you oblige us all.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Our Dinner ſtays for us, we'll ſettle thoſe things within: I have almoſt forgot the extraordinary Part of my Entertainment, I have a Pilgrim for you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: We have had him already.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And our ſhare of laughing at him too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: He pretends to be a Man of extraordinary Sanctity; I medled with that as little as I cou'd, for fear of raiſing a Spirit I cou'd not lay; beſides, I had matters of more moment to mind then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How did you get rid of him?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: With much ado I put him and his Hiſtory off, telling him, ſome Engliſh Hereticks were to Dine with me—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: We are oblig'd to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: And if he pleas'd to ſpare that miraculous Account, (which he will be ſure to give of himſelf) for the Converſion of the Wicked, he might then have a proper occaſion for ſo great a Deſign.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I ſhould think the worſe of my Conſtitution as long as I liv'd, if I ſhou'd grow qualmiſh of any thing he cou'd ſay to me.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I knew I muſt hear him, and therefore provided your Converſation to qualify his.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Novelty may divert us.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He profeſſes more Charity, than to force his Nonſence upon you.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: That Puniſhment I muſt go through, before he will go away, and pay for my Penance too.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: At the expence of his Vow of Poverty.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Pray Gentlemen, along with me.
I don't deſire you to believe all he ſays.
Take what you like, and laugh at all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, there our Chriſtian Liberty's confeſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Wou'd we had ne're a more impoſing Prieſt.
sp.stage: Ilford pulls Sir Antony by the Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: One word before you go.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Prithee come along— no Cautioning in ſuch a ſlight Affair—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I am glad you think it ſuch a ſlight Affair.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Meer merriment.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I never thought it more.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Matter of Mirth, and Jeſt.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay, that's too much.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Upon a fooliſh Pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Upon Volante.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Volante! Thou talk'ſt of Volante, and I anſwer thee, the Pilgrim: Why thou art diſtracted, Man; and I ſhall ſuſpect my ſelf to be no wiſer than I ſhou'd be, for keeping thee Company.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sir, however you think to carry it, I muſt tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: With a very Grave Face—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: This is no jeſting time—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Becauſe 'tis a ridiculous Subject.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: That I am in love—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: In ſerious ſadneſs.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: With that Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That never was ſad, nor ſerious in her life: Prithee, no more of this, Ilford, in Love! Thou art a very honeſt Fellow, and haſt a great many good Qualities, but thy Talent lies quite another way.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sir, I am ſerious enough to be angry, if you laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But you are in Love with her, you ſay: Why every body that ſees her, is in Love with her, if that wou'd do any good; but is ſhe in Love with you?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I think my Eſtate may recommend my Perſon to a Welcome, whereever I pretend.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Do's ſhe think ſo?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why do you ask the Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Volante is too Witty, to be very Wiſe; and requires no Settlement, but her Man.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And why may not I be her Man, pray?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Fy, Fy, Sir, more Modeſty might become a Man of your Gravity! You her Man! No, no, ſhe's otherwiſe diſpos'd of, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What, you follow her!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Nay, you follow her; ſhe does not put me to the trouble.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: No, Sir— I ſhall put you to more trouble, if you don't quit your Pretenſions to her—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Quit my Pretenſions to her!

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And promiſe me—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I will promiſe you—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, will you ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That (whatever I would have done by fair means) I will now follow her in ſpight of your Teeth—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: In ſpight of my Teeth—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Purſue her, till ſhe yield to my Deſires—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The Devil you will!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And lye with her under your Noſe.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You ſhall be Damn'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Nay, then have at the Lady.
sp.stage: Volante Entring, ſees 'em fighting, ſhrieks, and runs out, Sir Antony after her, and returns with her in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: This was a Trick to ſave his Cowardice.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I had rather part with my Pretenſion to a Quarrel, than to my Miſtreſs at any time.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I hope you are not hurt.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sir, you aſſert a Priviledge, the Lady never gave you, of Treating her at that Familiar rate.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: At what familiar rate?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Sir, you may be reſpectful, look ſimply, and bow at a diſtance, in a Modeſt Diſpair, of ever coming nearer to pleaſe; but I am for a cloſer Converſation, when I like my Company.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Sir, my Carriage gives Offence; but I muſt think you treat me more familiarly, that ſaucily ſhou'd dare to cenſure me, limit my Actions, and preſcribe me Rules.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A Fooliſh Fellow, Madam, not worth your Anger; leave him to his Repentance, and your Scorn.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I muſt bear it all.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: But pray, how came this Difference?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: 'Twas your Quarrel, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You may judge what a Husband he'll make, who (being but a Servant) dares aſſume an Authority over you—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Which I never gave him, that I remember.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I told you, you were out of the Road of her Favour.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The Report of this Quarrel, and the Occaſion of it, will be but a ſcandalous addition to my Fame, when it comes to be the Tattle of the Town.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: It ſhall go no further for me.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe the folly on't will keep you ſilent; you may be aſham'd on't indeed.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I beg you Pardon for it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Beg, Sir Antony's; for till he pardons you, I am ſure, I won't.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There is no Remedy, you muſt ſubmit.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I am a Woman's Fool, and muſt obey.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis many a Wiſe Man's Fortune.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: We are Friends.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: If you have Favours to expect from me, deſerve 'em by fair means.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Or come to me, and I'll ſpeak a good word for thee to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You Triumph, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Till when, we take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Pox! I deſerve it all,
For putting it into her Power to uſe me ſo:
He's Ten Years younger than I am,
And conſequently ſo much handſomer in her Eye:
He prates a great deal more, and better than I do
For her purpoſe, and therefore lies better in her Ear:
He has the Advantage of me, in every Vanity
That can betray a Girl; Volante's a Girl,
And what cou'd I expect for my honourable Love for her?
When, in the weakneſs of a Woman's Choice,
She will prefer the preſent laughing hour
To all that can come after.
If this wou'd cure me now, 'twere a Leſſon well learn'd:
I'll hear what the Pilgrim can ſay upon this Subject;
I'll liſten to his Lies, they are leſs miſchevious,
And may drive this Woman out of my Head.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is not that Sir Antony?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: With my Couſin Volante.
We ſhall have 'em at the turning of the Walk.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: They are proper Counſellors for our purpoſe of Diſobedience—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: As we cou'd ha' met withal.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You'll be no Nun, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nor you no Counteſs?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I wou'd be as willingly enclos'd in the Walls of a Monaſtery, as in the Arms of that Count Verole; and in the Arms of Death rather than in either.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well; I'm not ſo difficult; I had rather be alive upon any Terms, than dead upon the beſt; I had rather be a Nun, than be nothing at all; tho' there's nothing I had not rather be, than be a Nun.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Any Man's Company, rather than the Company of all Women.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: 'Tis more to my Humour, I confeſs to you, among the reſt of my Venial Offences; But Valentine! he is your Man, Siſter; wou'd I had the fellow of him—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: For your Confeſſour, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I cou'd confeſs ſomething to him that wou'd make him enjoyn me another kind of Penance, than my Prayers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What! Abſolve you from your Devotion?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And perſwade him to make a Sinner of me, rather than ſuffer my Father to make me a Saint, ſo much before my time.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You are a mad Girl: But what of Valentine?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He ſhou'd not be out of our Deſign.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'll anſwer for him, he won't.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: His Intereſt's ſo concern'd, he ſhould not be wanting in any occaſion of abuſing our Father.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Or of uſing the Count as he deſerves.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: They're both behind us, Mum—

div.stage: Count Canaile and Count Verole enter.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: I have prepar'd my Daughter to receive the Honour
You intend our Houſe and her, by this Alliance with us;
She too well knows what's owing to a Father and her ſelf,
To my Authority and her own Birth, now to diſpute
What I deſign for her; ſhe ha's my Will,
The reſt I leave to you—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Madam, you hear your Father, and I come
Thro' his Authority, to ſpeak my Love;
Tho' bateing his Authority, I muſt think
There need not many Arguments to move,
More than your knowing me, and what I am.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My Lord, that goes a great way with me, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: She knows you and your Qualities, my Lord,
And eſteem's 'em accordingly: I have heard her ſay,
She was very much oblig'd to you, and ſhou'd be more—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If he wou'd hang himſelf—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: For what, young Lady?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: For your kind Care of me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I'm glad you're ſenſible I mean you well.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: O yes, Sir, ſenſible! ſo ſenſible,
I muſt be oblig'd in Conſcience to thank you,
For adviſing my Father to ſend me to a Nunnery:
The Devil take you for your Advice.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: A Nunnery is Virtue's beſt Retreat from a bad World.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: But if my Siſters Fortune, in your Opinion,
Had not wanted mending more than my Manners—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Fy, Charlott, you'll tell all.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How cou'd ſhe gueſs at that?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I might have continued in this bad World,
For any Advice the Count wou'd have given,
In his great care of me to my Father;
But I'll be reveng'd on him—
Do as much miſchief as I can while I am in the World,
And repent when I am out on't, and can do no more.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Bring Sir Antony to my reſcue, I beſeech thee.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your Siſter's diſoblig'd,
But I've my ends in ſerving you—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: In ſerving of your ſelf:
For what I got by her, my Fathers ſays,
You muſt command.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: To make it but more yours.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: So you promiſe all before you have enclos'd us,
But poſſeſs'd, our Fortunes, and our Perſons are your Slaves,
Us'd like your Slaves, and often both abus'd.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: This is a common Subject for your Sex.
sp.stage: Sir Ant. Volante and Charlott enter.
sp.l: To boaſt the Glory of your Wit upon;
But I'm above the taſte of common things,
Being born above the Rank of common Men.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Out of the Rank, he means, of commen Men; and indeed, he ſcarcely looks of Humane Kind.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What do I look like then?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There's nothing like you, you are your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I wou'd be nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: What, not of God's Creation?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I am of his Creation.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Of the King's you may be; but he who makes a Count, ne're made a Man; remember that, and fall that mighty Creſt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: It ſeems you know me then.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: By that coy, cock't-up Noſe, that hinders you from ſeeing any Man, that does not ſtand upon the Shoulders of his Anceſtors, for long Deſcents of farr-fam'd Heraldry: I take you for a Thing, they call a Count; for had you not been a Count, you had been nothing, at leaſt I'm ſure you had been nothing here.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I would be nothing, if I were no Count.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Pray more reſpect.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: This is the Count Verole.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: O, is it ſo?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: That's to Marry my Cozen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I have been too bold, pray Ladies joyn with me—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: To laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To ask his Pardon.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: For the future, know me, and know your ſelf, I ask no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Then I am pardon'd, for I know my ſelf, and think I know your Worſhip. Can you fight?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ha! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why faith I come but upon a 〈◊〉 Embaſſie; and a ſinical Phraſe that wou'd fit the fineneſs of your Quality, wou'd not become my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What does the Gentleman mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Walk but aſide with me, I'll tell you what I mean.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You have no Secret for me?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why then it ſhall be none.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: He won't draw before the Women, ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Since the Ladies muſt be by, as they muſt be the Judges at laſt, you muſt know then, I come to you from a Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Is he no more?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: He's every thing in that, that makes a Man.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You may go, as you came, for me, Sir, if he be but a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: His name is Valentine, your Rival in that Lady.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: My Rival is my Equal; I am born above his Rank, he cannotrival me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: He does rival you, and will rival you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Envy he may my Fortune with that Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Well! Envy then, if that muſt be the Word; he envies you; and only wants an opportunity of telling you, how much he envies you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A modeſt Requeſt truly.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He can't deny it him—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Before his Miſtreſs too.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Now Sir, if you will be ſo courteous, as by me, who am to be his Second, to favour him with knowing where, and when he may wait upon you, you will oblige me by this Civility to ſerve your Friend, as he deſigns to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How may that be, pray?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To Cut your Throat, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: O Sir, I'll ſpare his Compliment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: My Friend's an Engliſh Man, and never loſes a Miſtreſs for want of fighting for her, I aſſure you: Nay, I have known ſome of my Countrymen, rather than not make a Quarrel in the Families they made love in, have beat their very Women into good Nature, and Conſent.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: It ſhou'd be good Nature for another then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Such Arguments wou'd not prevail on us.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Unleſs to Cuckold 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.l: For one reaſon or another,
There are Cuckolds every where.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How will our Count get rid of this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I wait your Anſwer, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: My Anſwer is, when I am as angry as your Friend is, which, at preſent, I have no reaſon to be; nor to a day, can certainly ſay when I ſhall be—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You muſt be made angry then.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: When I am under a defeat of my hopes about that Lady, as he may be, and, in an abſolute deſpair of better ſucceſs, and have nothing elſe to do with my ſelf, I may be angry, and then I may fight with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Muſt you be angry when you fight?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Or Mad, or Drunk; 'tis no Employment for a ſober Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Have you no Notion of Courage?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Notion indeed, young Man; for Courage is no more, than juſt ſuch a degree of Heat, to ſome Complexions natural; but thoſe Men, who want that Heat, may raiſe their Spirits to't.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I marry! there's a Receipt indeed.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Paſſion will fire the coldeſt Elements; the Lees of Wine ferment the dulleſt Phlegm to Froth and Vapour; I've ſeen a Drunkard in this Fit, attempt dangers to Rival Caeſar: If ſuch Extravagancies make the Brave, Madmen are Heroes.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: This won't do my buſineſs. Will you fight?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: 'Tis common Soldiers work.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You muſt fight with him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Not while I can hire Ruffians to take the trouble off my Hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You muſt expect to be us'd very ſcurvily, where-ever he meets you.
sp.stage: Valentine, Ilford, with Sir Gent. Golding Enter.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I ſhall be provided for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: O, here he comes himſelf.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: If you're for muſtring your Friends, I have your Father of my Party.
sp.stage: Exit in diſorder. Women laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Ladies never want an entertainment, when they have Sir Antony to encourage the Mirth. Pray what particular Diverſion has he given you?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Very particular indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You were a Party concern'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And only wanting to make up the Farce.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Yes, this is he, my very, very Fool!

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Very handſom Gentlewoman indeed, all three of 'em: and that's Sir Antony, that the Abbe commended ſo much.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The very ſame, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I will be acquainted with him—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sir Antony.—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Sir you moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Do you know me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Not I, but I'm an Engliſh-man, and the Engliſh always keep together Abroad, they ſay, for fear of being cheated.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Of their Money, or Manners?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Of their Mother Tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Of their Mother-Church, their Religion. Now I deſigning to continue, as I am—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Have a mind to ſpend my Money among my Country-men.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You're very welcome—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To be cheated only by your Friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: There's Valentine, a very pretty Fellow; but I have known him a great while; I am for Variety, and freſh Faces: Here's honeſt Ilford, my very good Friend, of half an hours acquaintance, will recommend me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You recommend your ſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Truly I hear you are an Extraordinary Perſon, and a Knight, Sir; I am a Knight my ſelf, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And an extraordinary Perſon truly: Pray of what Family, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Of what Family? Of my Father's Family before me; the Family of the Goldings, of which, I am your Servant, and Sir Gentle Golding.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Alas poor Count! I vow I pity him.
Where's this mad Knight? Oh!
sp.stage: Sees the two Knights in ſalutation.
sp.l: You are before me it ſeems; but ſince
I come too late to recommend Sir Gentle to you,
Pray do you recommend him to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: This is Sir Gentle Golding—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Sir, as I may ſay, I may thank you for this favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If you are for this ſport, I'll find you Game, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: O, of all things Ilove the Women.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir Gentle declares that by his Dreſſing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You ſhan't dreſs in vain, I'll find you employment among 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I'll depend upon you then, and from this time forward, we muſt be intimate as Men of the ſame Brother-hood, and Worſhip— ought to be.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: See, ſee, our Count has rally'd again!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: With your Father in his Tail, to ſuſtain him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We muſt not ſtay till they come. At Night I may expect you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If any thing extraordinary happens—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I'll come expreſs with the Tidings.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You ſhall hear from us.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Your ſervant, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You ſee, Sir Gentle, we make a ſhift.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Make Shift! We make a Carnival; all the Year a Carnival: Every Man his Woman, and a new one at every Town we come at.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Ah, wou'd I could ſay ſo too!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You ſay ſo, Sir Gentle? Fye, fye, you don't deſire to ſay ſo, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: That's very fine i'faith.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You only rally your Country Men.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Not I, as I hope to be ſav'd, Val, tho' I love a Joke, I never rally a Friend.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You a Miſtreſs! Why, you have forſworn the Sex!

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord! that's a likely buſineſs indeed! I forſwear the Sex! I wou'd as ſoon forſwear my own Sex, as the Womens; why, I have made it my indeavour, ever ſince I was a Man of Eſtate, to be accounted a Knight of Intrigue; ſo you never were more miſtaken ſince you were born, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, what a lying World we live in! I was told you were ſo ſcurvily us'd in England—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Softly, ſoftly, Man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By Lucia—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: A Jilting Jade! You knew her, not worth remembring.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That you were reſolved never to venture on the Sex agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Prithee, dear Val, no more on't: There's ſome ill Nature in my part of the Story; I wou'd not have it go further for my own ſake.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: It goes no further for our hearing it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: We know it already.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Ay, it may be ſo; I confeſs, poor Creature, I gave her a Jealouſie of another Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And that perhaps, in her Deſpair of pleaſing you much longer, might be a Reaſon of doing what ſhe did.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Why truly very likely.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And therefore ſhe robb'd you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Of 500 Pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: She might ha' ſhew'd a Conſcience in her cheating though! Five Hundred Pounds was too much in reaſon—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Sir Antony, you are my Friend upon all occaſions; but the truth is, I gave her an Opportunity; left my Cabinet open on purpoſe; and was glad to get rid of her for the Money.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You ſhall pay as round a Sum for this Lie, before I part with your Vanity.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And this is all?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: The ſhort and long of the ſtory.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Leave the ſilly Creature to her Garret, where ſhe will be in a little time: ſhe'll hang her ſelf in her Garters when the Money is ſpent.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I warrant her, will ſhe, and be glad to come off ſo too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: So, forgetting Diſaſters at home, you travel—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To drive and old Miſtreſs out of his Head.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And recover here, what he had loſt in England by the Gallantry of a French Intrigue—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Which I come qualified for, Gentlemen; being able to bid up to the Price of any of 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If you ſhew your Money, we may borrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: You may borrow, but I never lend; you are acquainted, and have your good Breeding and Behaviour to recommend you to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
