sp.p: You ſhew your Wiſdom in your good Husbandry, Sir Gentle; you are a Stranger, and muſt be oblig'd to your Pocket for what you muſt expect from 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: And therefore, Sir Antony, I will part with my new Acquaintances, my Luidores, to none but the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Money does every thing with the Women in France, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I won't ſpare it upon them, Sir Antony: I rely upon you for a Miſtreſs then.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee her this Evening.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Bills and Buſineſs, Gentlemen; but now we live together, no Ceremony: Adieu for a moment; and dear Sir Antony, yours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are in his favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And will be in his Pocket: Leave him to me.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Our Abbe and the Pilgrim agen! This Viſit is to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: He has a mind to make a Convert of me, that's certain; but whether in the Fleſh or the Spirit, is the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: He's for the outward Man, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And his Arguments of this World, whatever the Pilgrim's may be.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Ah my little Man! you have loſt a mighty Satisfaction; the Pilgrim has wrought Wonders upon us all within.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Much above my Expectation, indeed.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: His Story ſtaggers me, I confeſs; and has cur'd me of an old Diffidence I had of all Religious Pretenders.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Well, he's a Rogue; and you han't found him.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: You are the only Infidel in the Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You diſſemble a Belief; 'tis neceſſary to the Church, and you get by the Trade; but none of you remove Mountains, that I hear of.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Do but hear what he can ſay.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.l: I'll give him both my Ears—
But not a word here; I muſt have him to my ſelf,
To diſcover the bottom of him.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: 'Tis a work of the Spirit indeed; and the Spirit works unſeen of Human Eyes; therefore in private wou'd do very well.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Do as I order you.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: There is an obſtinacy in Sin, that won't be confuted before Company; Reproof may return into our own Teeth a Rebuke and a Reproach unto our ſelves. For which Reaſon I am aſſured, that a Privacy in Communication, and a Retirement from the eyes of the World (when the Cauſe is Conſcientious) are always neceſſary to a Conviction, and Converſion of the Wicked.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Thoſe Neceſſaries thou ſhalt have at my Lodging; I follow thee, Pilgrim: Farewel Gentlemen, if I am convinced in this Point, and live to ſet foot in England agen, I ſhall ſatisfie thoſe Heretical Unbelievers, that I have ſeen one Miracle in a Catholick Country.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Thus every Man to his own Intereſt tends;
The Pilgrim makes his Converts, We make Friends,
With the ſame Conſcience all, for our own Ends.

div.head: SCENE I. Waitwell placing Bottles on the Table.
div.stage: Enter Sir Antony and the Pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: THis is a dry Subject, Pilgrim; there's no engaging in't with out a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: You'll have your own ways here.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Have you infus'd the Opiate in his Wine?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: I warrant him he ſleeps for't; your's is half Water.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If I don't find him a Knave, I'll make him a Fool, for troubling me with his Impertinence: But chiefly, for the dear Jeſt of expoſing his Reverence to the Laughter of the Trophane.
sp.l: Have you done there?
Lock the door, and let no body come near us.
Now Pilgrim, we are alone; and ſit you down—
sp.stage: Pilgrim ſtands and Croſſes himſelf and Sir Antony.
sp.p: Nay, I will have no Bleſſing upon our Endeavours, but a Bumper—this will baniſh Croſſes: Here's to the falling of the Fleſh, and the riſing of the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: 'Tis a myſterious Health, of ſacred ſenſe; ev'n to the pulling down of Satan's Throne.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A little Wine does well to qualifie the Water you drink in your Pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Sometimes without offence, Wine may be us'd; tho' our whole Life is but a Pilgrimage—
sp.stage: Sir Antony fills agen the Glaſſes,

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That's as you pleaſe to make it. Come Sir, this is the Searcher of Hearts; here's to the opening of ours—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Hearts and Eyes, that we may ſee our Errors. This Wine will warm him, ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Confeſſion is a ſtep to Repentance, you ſay.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: The ready Road—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Then drink off your Glaſs, Pilgrim: How do you like your Wine?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: 'Tis warm, I promiſe you—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Able to diſtinguiſh a Saint from a Sinner; and will keep you out of the Mire, better than your wooden Shoes.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: 'Twill rather leave us there. But to our purpoſe now—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Another Glaſs to ſtrengthen my Attention; I ſhall edifie the better by it.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Sure he can't make me drunk.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I expected you wou'd ha' drunk to my Converſion.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I ſhou'd ha' began it in Charity, indeed; but I'll make you what Reparation I may, and drink a full Glaſs for my forgetfulneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I warrant him my own.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: To your Converſion be it—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: This is the way to't, and the pleaſanteſt Road you can travel in: For let me tell you, the World is bad enough at the beſt; we need not take Pains to make it worſe.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Too many do indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Such fooliſh Apoſtles as thou art then: Why, I begin to deſpair of thee: I took thee for a ſanguine, ſenſual Sinner, a Man of Senſe, and an Hypocrite. But I find thee a peaking Penitent, and an Aſs.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: You ſit in the Seat of the Scorner.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Tho' you paſs upon the Abbe, and other Fools, I expected you wou'd have open'd your ſelf to me: I profeſs my ſelf, what I thought you were under your Habit, a Rogue: We might have been of uſe to one another. But ſince you are for cheating no body but your ſelf, [Fills agen.] I'll make an end of my Bottle and Buſineſs, and leave you to ſay Grace to the next Courteſie I offer you.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I muſt not loſe this Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Now I begin to believe all the ſilly things you have ſaid of your ſelf; your being weary of, and leaving the World, when you had a good Share of it your own; your parting with the Pleaſures (which you call the Vanities) of it, at a time, when you were in a condition of enjoying 'em, by a ſenſeleſs reſigning up your Birthright.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: My Service to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Of a conſiderable Quality and Fortune to a Younger Brother; who indeed needed no other Expectation for his Wants, than the abundance of your Folly to live upon.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: You cenſure me too raſhly.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I ſpeak my Thoughts, and am ſo far from imitating you any way, that when an Elder Brother ſtood between me and a good Eſtate, I made bold to remove him.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: By no violent means.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Something before his time. I had a Joynture too incumber'd me; but a Phyſician after my own Heart eas'd me, and my good Lady-Grandmother.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: And dare you own it?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Not at a Barr of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: So horrid a Villany!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Never troubles me: I don't proclaim it but in my Cups, and where I think I'm ſafe to Men of my own Kidney—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: You confeſs your ſelf a Villain?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Any kind of Rogue that ſerves my turn; for I am of a Principle, that levels every thing in the way of my Pleaſure or Profit.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: A Worthy Principle!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I cheat the Men, and lye with the Women, as many as I can get in my Power.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Sir, I honour you; pray ſit down agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To hear you preach agen?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: And are you really this Rogue you pretend to be?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Are you the Fool you pretend to be?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I muſt come nearer you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: How, Jewels!

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I bring my Welcom with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Enough to ſet up a Saint: The Lady of Loretto may keep her Chamber; thou haſt ſpoyl'd her Holy-days, by robbing her Shrine: For thou haſt robb'd hers, or ſome other, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: 'Tis certain I have the Jewels: How I came by 'em, and why I put on this Habit—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Then you are no Pilgrim?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: No more than you are a Prieſt. I am as errant a Rogue as you can be; a Shifter of Shapes and Names; have travell'd through every Profeſſion, and cheated in all; ſo having by my Induſtry gathered a handſom Fortune, I converted that into Jewels, and my ſelf into a Pilgrim, for the ſafer conveyance of both into Spain, whither I was going till I lit upon you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I ſaw you through your Weeds, and had a mind to diſcover you.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Well, now you have diſcovered me—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why, now I like you.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: But are you ſure you like me?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Like you extreamly.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: If you can like me, you may love me too; for a Woman I know you are.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Am I diſcover'd too—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.l: Nay, I'm reſolv'd to like you in any Sex.
But it is impoſſible ſuch Beauty ſhould be a Man's:
And I will think you a Woman,
Till you convince me to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Have you a Miſtreſs to be convinc'd to the contrary?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: We were made for one anothers Converſation; here's that ſhall keep it in humour.
sp.stage: Lays his Hand on the Casket.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I have heard of Mark Antony's Pearl Cordial.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: You ſhall drink nothing elſe but Pearl diſſolv'd: Ha! What's the matter with me?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Now, now my Doſe begins— you grow indifferent—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: My Senſes vaniſh all.
sp.stage: Riſes, and ſtruggles all he can againſt it; but falls into his Chair aſleep.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: What fall a-ſleep before me?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: By and by I'll come agen to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.l: So, he's as ſafe as his Casket in my cuſtody: Governour, you may appear.
Here's an Oriental Preſent from the Mogul,
By the hands of his Embaſſador there.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: He looks as he were drunk-dead, or dead-drunk.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Examine his Pockets, lets ſee what Credentials he has for his Character, tho' you ſee I have treated him like an Embaſſador without 'em.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Here are Tablets full of Memorandums, to avoid ſuch and ſuch places where he has done his Rogueries.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Very well; theſe, when he awakes, will make good, if he ſhould have the impudence to diſpute my Title to the Theft.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: You won't keep all the Jewels?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A round Ranſom may redeem 'em; but him I muſt expoſe, Governour; when I ſend for him, bring him in a Chair to the Abbe's.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Moſt carefully.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And if Sir Gentle enquire for me, as I expect he will, direct him thither.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: I won't fail.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I have a Miſtreſs for him.

div.head: SCENE changes to the Street.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Volante is ſo buſie for another, ſhe has nothing to do for her ſelf; ſo cloſely employ'd for Valantine, ſhe has no Employment for any Body; or when ſhe has, 'tis partially deſign'd for that Boy-Knight, in prejudice of every Man that may with more reaſon pretend—
Sir Antony— Sir Antony— a word with you—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Prithee let me go; I am big with a Jeſt, and ſhall certainly miſcarry with the firſt grave Word you ſay to me.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Be deliver'd of your Burthen then, lay it at my door; I'll Father it for a Friend.
sp.stage: Bringing him back by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: As ſome Men wou'd a Baſtard, for the Reputation of getting it.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I have thought better of this Rivalling buſineſs between us; I ſee plainly Volante declares for you—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I think the poor Creature loves me indeed.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And 'tis to no purpoſe to proceed—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: None in the World, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: In the meaſures I had taken in making my way to her; therefore now I come, like a Friend, to deſire a Favour of you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Now you ſay ſomething, Ilford.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And like a Friend to adviſe you; you're a very pretty Fellow, and have a great many dancing years to trip over, before you come to be ſetious.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I hope ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You ſhou'd Ramble before you Settle—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: For fear of rambling after—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You are too great a Good, among the Women, to think of being particular; a dozen years too gay for the Condition—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Too gay for a Lover.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Too gay for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Ay, marry Sir, a Husband!

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I make Love ſometimes, but do not often Marry.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What do you follow Volante for then?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Can't you tell for what? For as good a thing you may ſwear, Ilford: You gueſs at her Inclinations, poor Rogue; and a Lady ſhall never loſe her Longing upon me; I deſign to Lie with her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Without marrying her?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Without asking any Conſent but her own; I am not for many words, when I have a mind to be doing.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: So impudent a thing I never heard!

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Quarrelling agen Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Upon the old Subject.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I hate the Employment and Character of an Informer: But you come ſo upon the ſcandalous minute, I muſt tell you what; that young Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir Antony has no Friend of you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nor you of him, Madam; as you will find, when you hear what he ſays of you.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Pray what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He has the Impudence not only to deſign it, but ev'n to me his Rival, who love and honour you—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Your Story, Oh, your Story!

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He dares notoriouſly tell me to my Face, That he never deſign'd to marry you; but becauſe you were in love with him, poor Creature, he wou'd do you the favour to Lie with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant
sp.p: Madam, you know he hates me upon your Account; and this is one of the poor Endeavours of his Malice to ruin me: You can't think I wou'd be ſuch a Villain—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I won't think it, Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Such an Ideot, if I cou'd have it in my head, to declare it to my Rival.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Oh no— it is not probable.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: By Heav'n and Earth he ſaid it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I wou'd not believe it for Earth and Heav'n, if he did.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis labour loſt.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: If you'll deliver this Letter to Valentine, you'll do him more ſervice, [Gives Ilford a Letter.] than you have me with your News— I won't leave you behind me, Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I'm going to the Abbe's, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Well! I cou'd almoſt wiſh, he wou'd lie with her, to convince her, tho' ſhe won't believe me, ſhe will him; and that, in time, will be a ſufficient Revenge upon her Folly.

div.stage: Enter Abbe and Valentine to Ilford: Count Verole, with Six Bravo's on the other ſide; they ſtare upon each other, and paſs on. Abbe, Val. and Ilford remain.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: The Count has his Gurd du Corps, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir Antony has Alarm'd him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He is in a ſtate of War, fit to give Battle already.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What he wants in his Perſon, he has in his Equipage: But they threaten too much, to do any Harm.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Do you ſecure your Perſon; Volante ſhall ſecure your Miſtreſs againſt him, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Here's a Letter ſhe gave me for you.

div.head: SCENE, The Abbe's Houſe.
div.stage: Pilgrim brought in a Chair: Sir Antony Love after it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Down with your Burthen; and place him in that Chair. So, this is as proper a Scene to recommend our Farce to the Family, as we can have—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Sir Gentle Golding is below, and wou'd ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.l: One of you bring him up—
sp.stage: To the Chairmen, who go out.
sp.l: Governour, he muſt not know you belong to me.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: I know your Deſign upon him; and I'll be gone to put things in Order to receive him—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To receive Valentine: He ſhall be welcome to me; but to deceive Sir Gentle.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: You are as buſie 〈◊〉 a Projector, ſome of your Plots muſt miſcarry,

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Ha! he begins to ſtir: How long will the Opiate hold him?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: If he wakes before the Company comes, you loſe your pleaſure of laughing at him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But I have a ſudden Though, may give us a better Diverſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Sir Antony, your moſt incomparable humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Sir Gentle, I've done your Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: With the Lady you promis'd me?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: With that very Lady; I've ſecur'd an Appointment for you; but being a Woman of Quality—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: There you oblige me for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Tho' ſomething decay'd, and fall'n in her Fortune— She muſt be humour'd in little things; ſhe will have her Forms.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I warrant her; and very fit ſhe ſhou'd. A Perſon of Quality is known by her Forms.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: They laſt but till the Evening, then I'll carry you to wait on her. Shews the Pilgrim.] Here's a drunken Pilgrim will afford you Merriment enough to entertain ſome part of the time.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Dead drunk, as I intend to live ſober.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Do me the favour to ſtay; and ſecure him, if he ſhou'd wake. I'll but bring the Abbe and his Family to ſhare in abuſing him, and be with you again.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p:
Why what an Unlucky, Hypocritical Rogue is this, to be diſcover'd,
and to lye at the mercy of Sir Antony! If he were but half as Holy, as he pretended, he might 'ſcape by Miracle; but he ſleeps ſo ſound, no Revelation can Wake him.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Boy, Draw the Curtain, Sirrah—
sp.stage: Turns in his Chair, and makes Signs of waking.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Is the Light in your Eyes, Sir? What pains he takes to come to himſelf! Gad, I'll play the Rogue with him—I'll be the Midwife to his Labour—Stay, let me ſee, a ſtiff Straw wou'd do rarely, to probe his Sobriety. If his Brain be touch't, he'll take up the more time in his Cure, and 'tis well if ever he be his own Man again. Now for the Experiment.
sp.stage: Tickling his Noſe, the Pilgrim jumps up, and throws Sir Gentle along, and in his thoughtfulneſs ſtumbles over him: both amaz'd, raiſe themſelves upon their bottoms, and ſtare at each other.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Ha! Am I alive? Where have I been? Where am I now? How came I here? Who are you? What wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Have! My ſelf in a Wiſh to England. Wou'd I were in my Mothers Belly again.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Speak, I conjure you, ſpeak to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: He's as heartily frightned, as I can be; I'll pluck up a Spirit, and ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Some ill thing has poſſeſs'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Yes, poſſeſs'd thou art, by the lowd Spirit of powerful Wine poſſeſs'd. A drunken Devil.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: A Bottle, and Sir Antony I remember, and the Diſcoveries I made him.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: You are diſcovered, and in the Abbe's Houſe—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: In the Abbe's Houſe!

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Where now your buſineſs is to be laugh'd at, and expos'd; and the whole Family are coming to make your Holineſs a Ridiculous Viſit to that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: That young Rogue Sir Antony! Has he done nothing elſe to me? [Examining his Pockets.] Undone, undone! I'm robb'd, and ruin'd: My Jewels gone! my Table-book gone too! That may do me more harm, than the Jewels can do any Body good.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Have you loſt your Learning? How cou'd you miſs it ſo ſoon? A Table-book?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Sir, I am robb'd; and I took you very ſuſpiciouſly about my Pockets; you ſhall anſwer the Robbery.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Why, do I look like a Pick-pocket? I'd have you to know, I ſcorn your Words: But that Trick ſhan't ſerve your turn—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Serve my turn, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: You muſt not 'ſcape me ſo.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.l: Why, Sir, am I your Priſoner? I muſt not be found here.
I have an Inkhorn may frighten him.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, here's the Inſide of my Pockets; I have nothing about me, but Bills of Exchange, and this Purſe of Elizabeth Broad Gold: You ſhall ſearch me, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I have ſearch'd you, and found you, and muſt go by you too—
sp.stage: Preſents an Inkhorn to his Breaſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, I don't hinder you—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: No, no, you had not beſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Pray take it away: I have a natural Averſion to the ſmell of Gun-powder—
Tho' 'twill be difficult to get away, for the Servants are order'd to ſtop you.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: How! to ſtop me!

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Now he wont offer to go.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: The Servants ordered to ſtop me, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: If you be the Pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Then I'll be the Pilgrim no longer—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: What will you be then pray?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Ev'n Sir Gentle Golding; I will get off in your Perſon, ſince I can't in my own; I muſt change Out-ſides with you—
sp.stage: Begins to undreſs Sir Gent. Gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, there's no Occaſion for it: I know nothing of a Deſign upon you.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: That's more than I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Faith and troth now, what I ſaid, was only to play the Rogue with you.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: And what I do, is to play the Fool with you. You muſt ſtrip Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: O, but this is carrying the Jeſt too far.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Look you, you may keep your Worſhip and Wit for your own wearing; but I muſt borrow your Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: At any other time, and welcom; I ſhould be pleas'd with the Humour on't; but this is my firſt day of wearing 'em; beſides, there's a Miſtreſs in the Caſe—
sp.stage: Dreſſes himſelf in Sir Gent.'s Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: As long as you live, prefer a Friend to a Miſtreſs, Sir Gentle; Come Sir, a little of your Aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: But I am to ſee her this Evening; and one wou'd be well dreſt you know, the firſt time.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: If you muſt ſee your Miſtreſs, Viſit her in Maſquerade; 'tis a faſhionable way of beginning an Intrigue— and a Pilgrims Habit— is as Fantaſtical, as you can contrive— to give a Lady a Curioſity— of knowing more of you— And that I know is your Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: That is my Buſineſs indeed: But if I loſe my time—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Don't make a noiſe, nor follow me; If you wou'd ſee her, or little England again, know your Friends, and give thanks Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.l: What a paſs have I bought my ſelf to, by my own
Policy! Why muſt I needs lye my ſelf out of my Cloaths?
If I had held my Tongue, or ſpoke but the Truth,
He wou'd ha' gone about his Buſineſs, without interrupting mine.
Now here I muſt ſtay, to be expos'd in his Room;
But in a fooliſher Figure, than ever the Pilgrim made:
He was only diſguis'd: But I am ſtript.
He was drunk indeed; wou'd I were dead Drunk,
To cover my Shame, any way; wou'd I had any Diſguiſe.
I Gad I'll put on the Pilgrim's— It can't be worſe with me—
Beſides, the reſpect that is paid to this Cloathing, will at leaſt
Carry me ſafe to my Lodging.

div.head: SCENE Changes to the Street.
div.stage: Pilgrim in Sir Gentle's Cloaths, with Monſieur Traffique.

sp.speaker: Traff.
sp.p: Sir, I have accepted theſe Bills already.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I know you have: But my Occaſions falling out more Extraordinary than I expected, I am forc'd to preſs you for this Bill of 100 Piſtols, before the Day.

sp.speaker: Traff.
sp.p: I have ſo often ſuffer'd, for thoſe Complemental Payments, that I have reſolv'd againſt 'em: But my Correſpondent gives me an account of Sir Gentle Golding; you ſhall have what Credit you pleaſe with me.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: A hundred Piſtols I have preſent uſe for.

sp.speaker: Traff.
sp.p: If my Caſhier were at home, you ſhou'd have 'em along with you; but in the Morning, as ſoon as you pleaſe—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I'll ſend my Servant to you— pray Sir, what news have you in the City?

sp.speaker: Traff.
sp.p: The neweſt Sir, is of a Pilgrim, that is ſuſpected of ſomething; I am Imperfect in the Particulars; but there are Warrants out to apprehend him, that I know.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: There's no believing Out-ſides; Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Traff.
sp.p: So I think too; And therefore I will be better Inform'd, whether you are Sir Gentle Golding or no, before I leave you.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: The hundred Piſtols, if I had receiv'd 'em, had carry'd me off cleverly, and for ſome time, ſupported my Deſigns, in another place, till an Opportunity had favour'd me in making a handſome Compoſition with Sir Antony about my Jewels— However, I make a pretty good Figure ſtill; Here's a good Suit of Cloats to begin the World with again—
sp.stage: Strutting and looking on his Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Bleſs your Worſhip, Sir Gentle, long may you live to wear 'em; How do your Cloaths fit you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Very well Friend, very well.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Have you forgot me, Maſter?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: No, no, I han't forgot thee; for I never ſaw thee before.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I am poor Courtaut, your Taylor's Finiſher; I brought your Honour's Cloaths home to you this Morning—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Did you ſo, did you ſo?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: By the ſame token, you ſaid, you wou'd give me ſomething to drink you health; but you were pleas'd to forget it.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I remember I gave thee nothing indeed; but the next time—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Aye, an't like your Honour, I am contented to ſtay, if my Maſter wou'd: But he has beaten me black and blew for leaving the Cloaths behind me, without Money.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Gad forgive me; that I ſhou'd forget that too! But come to my Lodging an Hour hence—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Pleaſe you, I'll wait upon you now to your Lodging—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: How ſhall I ſhake him off?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: For I dare not go home without the Money, or ſome part on't?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Here, take this Purſe, 'tis more than the Debt, but take the reſt for thy ſelf, now I remember thee—
sp.stage: Enter Traffique with a Servant of Sir Gentle's.
sp.p: The Elizabeth broad Gold has deliver'd me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Maſter Monſieur, that is my Maſter, Sir Gentle Golding. You ſhall ſee me ſpeak to him—

sp.speaker: Traff.
sp.p: Young Man, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: More Debts to pay! I ſhall fall like an Executor without Aſſets.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, I have been about your Buſineſs, with the Meſſenger, as you order'd me—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: This is one of my Engliſh Servants it ſeems; I'll anſwer him in French to get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: If you were at leiſure—

l.hi: Que Demandez vous? que dites vous Laquais?
Entendez vous le Francois, grand Coquen?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: How's this? I durſt ha' ſworn it had been my Maſter; but I am ſure he has no more Languages than Tongues and that his Mother gave him: Beſides he's too good an Engliſhman, to learn any thing in another Country.

p.hi: Je ne vous en tens pas, je ne parle pas Anglois.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: It ſeems I was miſtaken, Sir, this is ſome out-landiſh man; he can't ſpeak Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Traff.
sp.p: How, not ſpeak Engliſh!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I'm ſure he paid me for the Suit upon his back, but juſt now, in very good Engliſh—

sp.speaker: Traff.
sp.p: And wou'd have borrow'd a hundred Piſtols of me, in as Civil Engliſh—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I can ſpeak Engliſh Gentlemen, I ſpoke French, only to try, if that Fellow had learn't any thing, ſince he came into the Country.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I'll have a tryal with you. This is ſome Rogue that has murder'd my Maſter—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And ſtole his Cloaths—

sp.speaker: Traff.
sp.p: And robb'd him of his Bills of Exchange.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Murder, Murder; Roguery, Thievery, ſtop him.

div.stage: Enter Sir Antony, Valentine, Ilford, and Abbe.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay the Pilgrim was in the right, in getting off before your Evidence came upon him.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I never heard of ſo Extraordinary a Rogue, as he confeſſes himſelf to be in theſe Tablets.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But that our gentle Knight, ſhou'd neither hinder him from going, nor be forth-coming himſelf, makes me believe ſome Ridiculous Accident has light upon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Let it be but Ridiculous enough, and I may forgive him.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: The Ports are ſhut, and for the Pilgrim, if he be in the City, we ſhall have him again.

div.stage: Enter Sir Gentle in the Pilgrim's Habit.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What's that ſneaks by us ſo?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Our very, very Saint.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Good morrow Pilgrim!

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Won't you know your Friends?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: We were too late for your Levy. 〈◊〉 men of your Auſterity and Life never indulge the Fleſh, by ſleeping long; you are an early Stirrer.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Pray look up: You can do nothing ſure to caſt you down.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Ev'n the very ſame.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What do you in this Habit?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis whimſical and odd; I had a mind to try if you cou'd know me in this Diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: O yes, we know you in any Diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: But there's a Warrant out againſt the Pilgrim; you'll be taken up for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Why? you don't take me for the Pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But the Government will.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: The Government then, will take me for as very Raſcal as lives unhang'd in it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But what's become of him?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You were laſt with him—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You have convey'd him away.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Or murder'd him—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: You muſt anſwer for him, for you have his Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Nay if it be ſo, I'll tell you how I came by 'em—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The whole Truth, and nothing but the Truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I'll ſee him hang'd, before I tell a lye for a Rogue, that has us'd me ſo ſcurvily—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: How ſcurvily, dear Knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Why, when you left me you know, alone with him, he took his time, when my Back was turn'd; and clapt a Piſtol to my Breaſt—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Bleſs the Mark! a Piſtol!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A Piſtol, Sir Gentle!

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: A double Barrel'd Piſtol.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A brace of Bullets in each, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I warrant you there were: for he ſwore he wou'd ſhoot me thro' the Head—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The Piſtol was at your Breaſt, Sir Gentle.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Breaſt, did I ſay— Did I ſay, at my Breaſt Gentlemen? But Breaſt or Head Sir— He ſwore he wou'd murder me, if I did not give him my Cloaths, to make his eſcape in.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And ſo, you gave him your Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: No I thank you; that were to make my ſelf Acceſſory; I put him to the trouble of taking 'em.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: And very wiſely done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: So he ſtript you?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: To my very Shirt, I'll make Oath on't, before a Magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You put on his Cloaths then, as one may ſay, in your own defence?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: You may ſay ſo indeed.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Stick there Sir, Se defendendo will bring you off.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I muſt ha' gone home Naked elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And cou'd you have paſs'd ſullenly by us, and conceal'd ſuch an occaſion of Laughing at you?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Prithee Sir Antony, no more on't.

div.stage: Monſieur Traffique, Courtaut, and Sir Golding's Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Bring him along: Bring him along—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What Rabble have we here?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: We are enow to hang one Rogue, or we deſerve to beat Hemp for one another.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Where are you haleing the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Sir Antony, I am in your Power; ſtand but my Friend in this Buſineſs, and bring me off, you ſhall make your own Conditions about the Jewels—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I'll ſwear point-blank my Maſter's Murder upon him.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Who is your Maſter, Friend▪

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Gentle Golding, and like you; and I am his Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Aye, 'tis my Man indeed, wou'd I were his Maſter again.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You my Maſter, you Raſcal! my Maſter's a Knight—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Now Abbe, I am even with you and your Pilgrim: But ſince I have brought him ſo far into his Buſineſs, 'tis matter of Conſcience to bring him out agen. I was provided for his Impertinence; and ſince I cou'd not make him drunk, I gave him an Opiate to expoſe him as if he were; for that purpoſe I remov'd him to your Houſe: But coming to himſelf before I expected, he ſcap'd that Deſign—

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: And finding the Diſgrace ready to fall on me, and in your Houſe, I made bold to change Cloaths with Sir Gentle Golding—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: But ſince Matters are brought to a clearing, I am ready to return 'em to the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: As you had 'em, I hope?

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: Every thing but his Purſe; which I was forc'd to give his Taylor there to get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Return the Purſe.

sp.speaker: Traf.
sp.l: I'll ſee your Maſter paid.
The hundred Piſtols are ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: For Sir Gentle Golding, I only haſten'd you.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Why, how did you know I wanted ſuch a Sum?

sp.speaker: Traf.
sp.p: It ſhall be pay'd to you, or your order.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Pray pay it to no body elſe.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: You've done your Duty, Gentlemen; 'tis very well. Pilgrim, a word with you.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How this fooling has run away with the time!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I'll be for you immediately.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Within a quarter of Ten already!

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I ſhou'd ha' been glad to ha' made one, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I thank you; but Numbers may diſcover us, and Sir Antony won't be out of the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Do me but this piece of Service, and I won't only pardon you, but reward you well when you ha' don't. Beſides, 'tis a kind of Revenge upon Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I am at your Mercy, and you ſhall command me any thing.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sir Gentle ſays, you drew a Piſtol upon him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That was not according to the Law of Arms.

sp.speaker: Pilg.
sp.p: I can't tell how his Fear repreſented it, but it was an Inkhorn that diſarm'd him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You won't fail, when I ſend for you?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I'll but change Cloaths with that Gentleman, and be ready as ſoon as you pleaſe.
sp.stage: Exeunt Sir Gentle, Pilgrim, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Now Valentine have with you—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: 'Tis near upon your appointment with my Niece: I'll ſecure her Father within, the better to favour her running away from him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I wiſh you well, Gentlemen.
sp.stage: They go out ſeveral ways, Ilford and the Abbe; out Sir Ant. and Valent. together.

div.head: SCENE changes to the Back-ſide of a Great Houſe with Gardens.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: To morrow; let but once to morrow come,
And ſhe is mine; Marry'd, and wholly mine:
If then not wholly mine, 'twill be my Fault.
Gentlemen, we muſt be every where to Night:
This Engliſh-man, that dares to Rival me,
May attempt farther; if he ſhou'd, I think
Floriante but too inclin'd to pardon him.
But we'll prevent the worſt.
sp.stage: Valentine and Sir Antony make the Signal at the Garden-door, which opens upon it. Floriante retires upon the Noiſe of Swords, crying Murder.
sp.l: Stand and obſerve their Motions.
Nay, then 'tis he; be ſure you
Murder him.

div.stage: Count Canaile, with Sword in Hand, runs to aſſiſt Valentine and Sir Antony againſt the Bravo's.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Villains and Murderers, I hope you are not hurt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thank your Aſſiſtance, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If I am not a Man in this point, I'll never wear Breeches more.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I know 'twas Count Verole.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: He has not rais'd himſelf in my Eſteem by this baſe Action—

div.p: What do you out of doors?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I cou'd not ſtay within, knowing your Danger.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: 'Tis over, now retire.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Pray pardon me; if I have done any undecent thing, my Duty caus'd it in my Fears for you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I'm ſorry I have allarm'd your Family.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I dare ſwear for him he is

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: So far 'tis well, Sir: If you think your ſelf oblig'd for what is paſt, ſhew it in what's to come; forbear my Houſe, my Daughter is diſpos'd of: So good-night.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Very good Advice, Valentine: Since you can't make it a good Night with his Daughter, make it as good as you can with ſome body elſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why Faith, the Expectation of her has rais'd me into a deſire of any thing in Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: What think you of my Engliſh Lady?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You owe me a Favour there, Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To Night I'll pay it then; I have an Appointment upon me now; but not being in ſo perfect a Condition to oblige her, you ſhall make an End of my Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I'll ſend my Governor to conduct you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: He, like other wiſe men, makes no ſcruple of Pimping, when he gets by the Employment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Then you are not one of thoſe fine Gentlemen, who becauſe they are in love with one Woman, can lie with no body elſe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not I, Faith Knight; I may be a Lover, but I muſt be a Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.l: When the dear days of Rambling Joys are o're,
When Nature grudges to ſupply your Whore,
There's Love enough for Marriage left in ſtore.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Waitwell diſguis'd, with Sir Gentle Golding.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: SIR Antony not being able to wait upon you in Perſon, as deſign'd, has deſir'd me his Friend—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: To ſhew you the way.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I'll ſhew my good Breeding, and follow you.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: The Lady is at preſent in private; when ſhe has diſpatch'd her own Buſineſs, ſhe'll be ready for yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Then ſhe's a Woman of Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: And of Diſpatch too, Sir: If you love Pictures, there's a Gallery will take up your Thoughts till the Lady's at leiſure to employ 'em better. I'll let her know you're here.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p:
How Ceremony diſguiſes any thing! I can't take this civil Gentleman for a Pimp, tho' I have Occaſion for him; nor this Houſe for a Bawdyhouſe, tho' I have a mind to make it one. Wou'd Sir Antony were here, to
encourage me with his Impudence: When I have Company to halloo me, I can faſten like a Bull-Dog. But I have a villanous Suſpicion, that when I ſee this Lady, I ſhall take her for a civil Gentlewoman; a buſe her, away, ſhe does not deſerve; think too well of her, and looſe my labour.

div.head: SCENE changes to a Bed-Chamber.
div.stage: Valentine following Sir Antony Love in her Woman's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Faith Madam, your Entertainment will keep you in Countenance; you may own the making of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You'll truſt your Stomach with a cover'd Diſh another time, Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You may ſhew your Face after it, and expect the Thanks of the Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And diſgrace the Reputation I have got with you in other things.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, if you think ſo, I wou'd not have you ſhew it for the World.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That were to ruin the Complement you intend me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But after all, if your Face ſhou'd be as delicate as your other Charms—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But if it ſhou'd not be as delicate—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then keep it to your ſelf; but 'tis pity 'tis not: but be it what it is, I will pay ſome part of my Thanks in adviſing you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You wou'd ſay Grace and be gone, my ſerious Sinner, wou'd you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Only to make ſure of coming agen Child, that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Some of that all, I beſeech you—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Doctrine will turn to thy uſe. Child, and lead me often to thee, if thou haſt but the Grace to make the right Application.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Good Holder-forth, bate your damn'd Faces, and begin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why then, in the firſt place, about our Friend Sir Antony; He's a very pretty Fellow I grant you; but he's a Boy, a giddy-pated Boy—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A little too young indeed to be truſted—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: In an Affair of this nature, by any Woman that has a Reputation to ſecure with her Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I have been afraid of his talking indeed a great-while.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You muſt expect it, Madam; he has not Experience enough to value you: All Women are alike to the young Fellows; as indeed all Fellows are alike to the young Women; neither Sex chuſes well, till they come to an Age of Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There I am with you indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: There is a maturity requir'd in Love, as in other Fruits, to recommend the true reliſh of it, to the diſtinguiſhing Palate of an Epicure. I am ſomething a better Judge of that pleaſure, than he can be: And I think fitter, a great deal, for an Intrigue with your Ladyſhip, both in diſcretion and performance—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Then Sir Antony can be.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir Antony in Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But are not you a Rogue, Valentine? Not to receive a Courteſie from a Lady by the favour of your Friend, but you muſt abuſe your Truſt, and ſupplant the very Intereſt that rais'd you to her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am confounded indeed! But are you Sir Antony Love?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: All but my Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And are you ſure you're a Woman?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Are not you ſure of that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am; and charm'd with the certainty—
Now every pleaſure paſt, comes o're my thoughts:
How many opportunities have I loſt,
That you have giv'n me, and muſt anſwer for!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There are as many to come; you ſhall command 'em all.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Now I remember; you father'd a Baſtard for me, at Paris—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I had the reputation of it indeed; and ſhou'd have had the Cow with the Calf; for her Father purſu'd me to marry her, thro' all means of Accommodation, into the ſtrait at laſt of confeſſing my Sex to the Engliſh Embaſſador—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This you never told me before.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: He had her puniſh'd, and ſecur'd me in his Family, as long as I ſtaid there; for you know, he was a Man of Honour—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And a Man of Gallantry too, Madam, that knew which way to improve ſuch a piece of good Fortune—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: As well as any body; and ſo he did Valentine: By his generoſity and good uſage, he preſs'd me ſo very far, that not being able to anſwer the Obligations I had to him, (having you in my head at that very time) I was forc'd to run away from him, to get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How could you keep this from me ſo long?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Now 'tis more welcome to you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Had I known it before, it had been in my power—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Not to marry me, I hope, Valentine! But if you cou'd be in that mind (which I neither deſire, nor deſerve) I know you too well, to think of ſecuring you that way.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But I wou'd not have engag'd my ſelf, any where elſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I know your engagements to Floriante; and you ſhall marry her. That will diſengage you, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You continue your Opinion of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Floriante, I grant you, wou'd be a dangerous Rival in a Miſtreſs—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing can Rival thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And you might linger out, a long liking of her, to my uneaſineſs, and your own; but Matrimony, that's her ſecurity, is mine: I can't apprehend her in a Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Well Governour, what think you of my Management?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Why, if you take but half the pains in your Profit, that you have ſpent in your Pleaſure, I think we may expect a very good account of the Knight—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir Gentle Golding! he's in your Debt indeed: I had not leiſure to remember him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: We'll laugh at him at leaſure.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: He's in the Gallery, expecting your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: My pleaſure is to ſee him, bring him in.
I promis'd him a Miſtreſs, you muſt know: 'Twill be fooliſh enough to obſerve him, when he diſcovers me; pray ſtay, and laugh with me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Interview muſt needs be ridiculous.

div.stage: Sir Gentle Golding introduc'd by Waitwell: He is ſurpriz'd at the ſight of Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: My Office ends, where the Lady begins; I'll leave you to her.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, a word with you—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: The ſewer the better, till you have ſaluted her: You ſee ſhe expects it.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I ſhou'd have ſaluted her indeed: but the ſurprize of your Beauty, Madam, made me forget my Complement.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: My Face has ſurpriz'd him, I believe.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Pray, did I never ſee this Gentlewoman before?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: You beſt can tell that, Sir; but you are concern'd at ſomething.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: A little concern'd, I am indeed, but 'tis only to know, whether I know her, or no.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: In your Tour of France, you may have ſeen her; ſhe's of the Country.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: A French Woman.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Of Languedock.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I durſt ha' ſworn ſhe was an Engliſh Woman!

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Born and bred among us.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I'm glad on't, with all my heart. For I knew a little Woman, but a great Divel, ſo like her in England—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Very like, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: That faith and troth, I was down-right confounded at the ſight of her.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Some Miſtreſs, that you have forſaken—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: O fie, Sir, I never do thoſe things—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: I warrant you, and the guilt of her ill uſage haunts you up and down, in her ſhape.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Nay, I deſerve it indeed; if it ſhou'd be ſo; for I was too barbarous to the poor Devil, conſidering I was the firſt that undid her.
sp.stage: Sir Antony making a Courtſie, points Sir Gentle to a Chair.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: See, Sir, the Lady wou'd have you ſit down by her; I never ſaw her make ſuch Advances before; you are very much in favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Soft and fair. I muſt be more in your favour, before I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: She does not ſpeak Engliſh. But there's an univerſal Character in Love, which every Creature can comprehend; when ſhe has you alone, ſhe'll grope out your meaning, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: So, ſince we have nothing to ſay to one another, we ſhall loſe no time in Complements; I like her exceedingly: tho' I never look upon her, but Lucia comes in my thoughts; ſhe's ſo very like that jilting Jade, I ſhall never love her heartily: A week will be the fartheſt, I ſhall be conſtant to her. What ſign ſhall I make, to put her in mind of her Bed-chamber? Money ſpeaks all Languages, this Purſe will be my Interpreter.
sp.l: Voulez vous, Do me the grand Favour—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p:
But how ſhall we do to underſtand one another? You ſpeak no
French, and I ſpeak no Engliſh; 'Tis impoſſible to underſtand one another.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Madam; you do ſpeak Engliſh—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I underſtand it a little; enough to know I reſemble one. What did you call her, Lucia, aye, Lucia, a jilting Jade; you don't like that, for that reaſon you can't love me heartily; nor be conſtant above a Week: I underſtand ſo much, without ſpeaking Engliſh; as you find to be underſtood.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I find I do underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But I'll try to ſpeak plainer to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Nay, you ſpeak plain enough, Mrs. Lucy. Wou'd I were any where, to be rid of you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You ſee, we were not to part ſo. Fortune will have me oblig'd to you: I have almoſt ſpent the 500 l. I borrow'd of you.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I'm glad I had it for you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And faith, 'tis very kind, in an old Acquaintance, to follow me into France, to ſupply me agen: I know you came a purpoſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Not quite a purpoſe.—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: No, not quite a purpoſe, ſome little Buſineſs by the by of your own, you might have, I grant you: But this Purſe you never deſign'd for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I'll force nothing upon you Madam; you may give it me agen, if you don't like it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Yes, yes; the Purſe is an amiable Purſe, and very well to be lik'd; only the Sum does not amount to my Occaſions: There's no retreating, Sir Gentle, you are in my Power, and without a Ranſome, muſt continue my Priſoner; you know I never want a Piſtol upon theſe occaſions; 'tis not the firſt time I have robb'd you.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Any Compoſition; but don't murder me; you know I hate a Piſtol.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: What have you in your Pockets? Nothing but Papers?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: You have got already, all the Mony I had about me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: About you! with a pox to you: muſt I be ſo anſwer'd? And why had not you more about you? Stay, here's a Bill of 100 Piſtols, at preſent, ſhall excuſe you—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis very well it does.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Payable to you, or your Order? What's there?

div.p: Run, and receive this Bill for the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: He ſhou'd Indorſe it firſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you muſt lend me your Order.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: No borrowing among Friends; I'll give it you, to Monſieur Traffique.
sp.stage: Writes, and gives Sir Ant. the Bill, and Sir Ant. gives it to Waitwell, who goes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why, that's well ſaid.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: You live as it were by your Wits; 'tis better I ſhould looſe a little Money, then you ſhould forget your Trade, for want of employment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A great deal better, Sir Gentle! But I muſt lock you up till the Money be paid.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Aye, aye, with all my heart; but he won't ſcruple the payment.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p:
The next time I do you this ſavour, take care to be better provided;
don't let me loſe my labour upon you, I ſpeak as a Friend to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I'll take your Advice.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If I were not juſt upon my leaving the Town, and in a very great haſte, I can tell you, you ſhould not get off ſo eaſily.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I am beholding to you: But I am ſorry we looſe you ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You may find me again, if Chriſtendom ſtands were it does a Twelve-month to an end; let not that trouble you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thus all things are provided for by Fate:
The witty Man enjoys the Fool's Eſtate.
So Rich and Poor, let 'em compute their Gains;
One has his lot in Lands, and one in Brains.
And 'tis but Juſtice Fortune ſhou'd do more
For him, who being born ſo, wou'd be poor.

div.head: SCENE changes to the Street.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I allow all you ſay: And laſt Night's Action has not declin'd the Count from my Eſteem, more than it raiſes Valentine.

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: He'll keep your Daughter more orderly then a Nunnery can: ev'n let him marry her.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: You know, I'm out of my own Power and Choice.

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: Hang your Choice; you may be aſham'd on't.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Indeed I do repent it; but my word and reputation are engag'd to him.

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: Is that a man to make a Grandfather?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: No other ſhall, by Floriante, make me one: And therefore ſhe ſhall be Religious, and take the Habit in her Siſter's room—

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: What, make a Nun of her, againſt her Will!

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: To cut off all Pretenders; but to prove how I regard your Friend, Charlot you know, inferiour in nothing but her Years, if Valantine likes her, ſhe has my leave, and ſhall receive his Viſits at the Grate: Let him but conquer her, he has gain'd me.

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: Let him get Floriante, and he conquers thee.

div.p: Ah my little Palmer! You lye as cloſe as a man in a Proclamation; but you are a Pilgrim of Honour, I find—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Where I am engag'd, Sir—

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: Sir Antony can never diſcover thee.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: I warrant I do your buſineſs—

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: And your own buſineſs—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: My own buſineſs to be ſure, and Sir Antony's too, or I ſhall looſe my Labour.

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: About it, about it inſtantly, and proſper, my little Palmer.

div.stage: Enter Valentine with Sir Antony and Sir Gentle.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Valentine! I have ſome News for you:

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But you amaze me, Sir Gentle—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: It wou'd amaze one indeed, Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis the oddeſt piece of Roguery and Impudence that I have heard of.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Aye, ſo 'tis, 'tis pretty odd, and impudent indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A cheating Gypſie; I warrant ſhe has had her eye upon you, from your firſt coming to Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Nay, not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I began to ſuſpect her my ſelf, ſhe preſt me ſo often to bring you.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Ah; if I had known that, Sir Antony!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why, what if you had?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Why, I wou'd ha' ſtaid away; but if you had been with me, it had been the better for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Much at one for that, I believe. But is ſhe gone out of Town, do you ſay? You ſhou'd have apprehended her—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Pugh, pugh— ſhe's gone from her Lodging, ſhe muſt not ſtay long in a place.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis very well ſhe's gone—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Aye, ſo it is: and I hope I ſhall never ſee her agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I dare ſwear for him, he ſpeaks his heart.

div.p: Well Sir— your buſineſs with me? If it be grave or wiſe, keep it for your own uſe; I never approve diſcretion in any man, but a Pimp.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Sir, you may ſay what you pleaſe, or call me what you pleaſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I honour you, if you are one.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Then I am one, and one employ'd to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Begin your Employment, that I may go about mine.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, in few words; there's a Lady dying for you—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I never viſit the Sick, let her die in peace: But don't let a Prieſt come near her; he'll ask her bawdy Queſtions, when ſhe has a mind to be ſerious.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: She's only dying for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Were ſhe living for me, I cou'd ſay ſomething to her; if ſhe make a Will, as far as the Legacy goes, I may remember her.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Your Mirth becomes you, Sir; but the Lady's in very good health, and, in ſhort, only dying in love with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Short and ſweet.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: And has a mind—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I know her mind; and what ſhe has a mind to.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: You know the World enough, Sir; to excuſe a Lady in Love—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And abſolve her too.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Tho' ſhe ſhou'd have a Husband—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: For making him a Cuckold—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Not to make a practice of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: The oftner the better.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Nay indeed; there's a great deal to be ſaid for the poor Women;
How can they help or avoid their Inclinations?
Men are too blame, who like young Conjurers, prove
(Safe in the Circle of a Wedding-Ring)
The Magick Spell of Wedlock upon Love:
So, Cuckolds make themſelves by marrying.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Very Caſuiſtically brought about, Sir. And I am ſo much of your Opinion, that I think the Lady cannot do her ſelf a better juſtice, nor me a greater favour, than allow me to wait upon her on ſuch an occaſion.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: That ſhe does in this Billet: And if you think it worth your while to viſit her— will do you richer, and greater favours.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I am at preſent engag'd—But in the Evening—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: The Evening wou'd do well: I am bad to ſay, her Husband's out of Town, the reſt, her Note will beſt inform you in.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Then this ſhall be my Guide.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: I may cheat you out of your Cunning, before I ha' done with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why, what the Devil am I engaging in agen! I ſhall draw all the Women in Town upon me, at this rate: Maids, Wives, and Widows, have one Curioſity or another always to be ſatisfi'd. I have a Reputation among 'em; and if I don't keep it up, by anſwering their Expectations—I ſhall fail of mine, in my Frollicks, and be diſcover'd; and that I have no mind to be yet a while! But how the Devil ſhall I anſwer their Expectations—Or this Lady's in particular, who has beſpoke me for her Evening Service? If I go, I ſhall diſappoint her more than if I ſtay away; and I know, good Soul, ſhe wou'd be as much concern'd for me, to find me no Man, as at another time ſhe wou'd be for her ſelf, to be found no Maid, if ſhe had a mind to be thought one. O here comes Valentine!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I wou'd as ſoon be a Lawyer as a Lover at this rate. Following a Miſtreſs to no purpoſe, is as bad as trudging a Foot to Weſtminſter for no Fee. Can you corrupt a Nunnery for me, my little Knight!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I will do any thing for you—but firſt you muſt lend me your Limbs, to carry on a Deſign—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Do what you pleaſe with me.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Thou art a moſt incomparable Fellow, Palmer; the Prince of Pimps and Pilgrims! But what! Sir Antony is a young ſmoaky Rogue I warrant you, he ſuſpected ſomething—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Not a bit of ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: He might ſcruple it at firſt, you know.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Firſt nor laſt, he made no ſcruple at all! But came into my Net, as faſt as I cou'd ſpread it for him!

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: But came into my Net, as faſt as I cou'd ſpread it for him! Prettily expreſt upon the occaſion! And I ſhall love a Setting-dog, as long as I live, for the ſake of the Simile.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: I'm glad it pleaſes you.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Pleaſes me! Yes, yes; it pleaſes me! every thing pleaſes me. But ha! my Boy! he muſt not get from us, now we have him in the Net.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: 'Tis our fault, if he does.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why Sir Antony has us'd thee but ſcurvily—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: To my Coſt.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: And Revenge is very natural—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: And very ſweet.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Revenge is ſweet indeed; it muſt be ſweet; a ſweet Revenge, upon ſo ſweet a Boy: And take my Word; I'll do you that Juſtice upon him: For I'll tell you, what I intend to do with him—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Aye, pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why in the firſt place I intend — not to open my Lips, upon that Subject. But I mean—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: I hope ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: If I can compaſs my deſign, I mean—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Not to explain my ſelf, Palmer—Ah Rogue! But you know what I mean.

div.head: SCENE changes to Sir Antony's Lodging.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why to tell you the truth, Ilford, there is a Woman in the caſe; I expect her every minute.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I fancy'd ſome ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: She is a thing to be fancy'd; and you wou'd think ſo, if you ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Do I know her, Sir Antony?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You have ſeen her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What nothing more of her?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: None of your peeviſh Queſtions.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: 'Tis not Volante?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If it were, you don't come to quarrel for her?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Not I faith, Knight: I come in abſolute good Nature to viſit you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why indeed, I could not expect the favour at your hands, as Matters ſtand between us.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nothing ſhall ſtand between us: Nothing did, but a Woman; and I come to ſtrike up a Friendſhip, offenſive and defenſive with you, by making a very fair offer to diſpoſe of her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If you mean Volante, ſhe will diſpoſe of her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I know ſhe wou'd diſpoſe of herſelf to you: But you won't marry her, Sir Antony: Now I am one of thoſe fooliſh Fellows, who don't apprehend a Danger, till they are in't. I never think of being a Cuckold: I love Volante, and wou'd marry her— Come, come, there are Women enow for the ill-natur'd purpoſe of your Love; quit her to me, do a generous thing to a Woman that loves you; and to a Man, who would engage you for a Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why Faith, Ilford, I wou'd do a great deal for you; but I muſt do ſomething for her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Do me a Favour, and don't undo her Fame.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But there's the pleaſure on't—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To ruine the Woman that loves you—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Not ſo much out of ill Nature to her, as good Nature my ſelf: Reputation muſt be had: And we young Men generally raiſe ours out of the Ruine of the Womens.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
But Volante is a Woman of Quality,
And has Relations to do her Right, if you don't do her Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Wou'd ſhe had a Brother, to make a buſineſs on't: He cou'd not do her ſo much right, in fighting for her, as he wou'd do me reaſon, in making it the talk of the Town.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: That wou'd ſet it about indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If I ſhould ſay, I had lay'n with her; or endeavour to ſet it afoot, 'twould fall of it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: As an impotent Piece of Vanity, or Folly in a young Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But no body dares make a doubt of a Report, when a Relation has taken an honourable Care, by a Duel, to fix the Scandal in the Family.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why, truly I think the Men of Honour are out in that buſineſs: Scandal does not fall into the hands of a Surgeon, like the Wounds of the Body for a Cure: Opening and Probing, makes the Malady but more inveterate, and the leaſt Air taints it to a Mortification.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: It heals beſt of it ſelf, without a Plaiſter.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And Time muſt finiſh the work. I have obſerv'd ſome Women live themſelves into a ſecond Reputation—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And other Women, who by a natural Negligence, never ſetting up for any, from the freedom of their behaviour, have paſs'd uncenſur'd in thoſe publick Places, and Pleaſures, which wou'd have undone Ladies of a ſprucer Converſation, but to have appear'd in.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: So that 'tis not what they do, but not doing all of a Piece, that ruins their Character, and unders the Women—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And condemns the Men too: For 'tis not any Man's Opinion, but his ſhifting it to the Occaſion, that makes him a Raſcal; as let his Opinion be what it will, if he continues the ſame, and acts upon a Principle, he may be an honeſt Man: But 'tis no Character I wou'd adviſe a Friend to.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But this is from my buſineſs, Sir Antony! And, all things conſider'd, the difficulties of getting, and the danger of enjoying Volante; in my Opinion, her Woman wou'd be the better Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why indeed the Woman wou'd often be the better Intrigue, were ſhe as difficult to be compaſs'd as her Lady.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: It ſeems the danger doubles your delight.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And we naturally covet, what we are forbid; for very often 'tis the bare pleaſure of breaking the Commandment, that makes another Man's Wife more deſirable than his own.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: As at preſent, the bare pleaſure of oppoſing my Intereſt, has carry'd on yours with Volante, farther then otherwiſe you deſign'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why faith, there's ſomething in that too, Ilſord: Not but I have a very good Opinion of the Lady.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Well Sir Antony, I wiſh you wou'd think it worth your while, to make a Friend of me—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I wou'd make a Friend of you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Reſign your Title then: 'tis but giving me now, what in a little time you will decline of your ſelf: Make Volante mine, and make me yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I wou'd with all my heart; if I cou'd do it with Honour.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I warrant you with Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But how can I diſengage my ſelf? Matters are gone a great way between us— ſhe's coming up to me. [Waitwell, whiſpers and goes out.] Step into that Cloſet, you will over-hear what we ſay; I won't promiſe I can do you any ſervice with her. But I'll do you all the good I can; that you may be ſure of, and depend upon.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: At leaſt, ſeeing her here, will do ſome good upon me

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: O Madam, you as are good as your word.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I can keep it, you ſee, at your coſt, when I like the occaſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: We men are not more punctual to an appointment, upon the hopes of a new Miſtreſs, then you Women are, upon the firſt promiſe of a Husband.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: And it ſtands us upon to be diligent in both Sexes. For neither the Men, nor the Women, continue long in the mind of allowing thoſe Favours.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why faith, Child, the beſt Excuſe for fooliſh things— (As Marriage you allow to be one—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: A convenient fooliſh thing.)

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Is the doing 'em without thinking. But, what Madam, can't a Man ſport off a little innocent Gallantry with a Lady, without being ſerious a 'both ſides; You are in earneſt, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Why there's the Jeſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And keep me to my word.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: On my word will I

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You take all Advantages.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I may be allowed to take what Advantage I can ill the beginning; I ſhall be ſure to be the looſer in the end.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: In all Plays, one ſide muſt be the looſer; but Marriage is the only Game, where no body can be the winner.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: That's making an ill Bett indeed, where we may looſe, and can't win; Yet I am reſolv'd to venture.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But Child, haſt thou no more mercy upon my Youth, my Dreſs, my Wit, and good Humour, then to make a Husband of me!

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Since you could not have me on your own Terms, I know you'll take me on mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Well, there's nothing but cheating in Love: Very often indeed we are before-hand with the Women; but when we marry 'em, I'm ſure they cheat us.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: And when do I cheat you, Sir Antony?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Have a care of cheating your ſelf, Madam?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Nay, one time or other, all Women are to be fool'd; and I had rather you ſhould have the profit of me, then any Body elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And pleaſure too, I beſeech you. I am now going with Valentine to the Nunnery, to ſee his new Miſtreſs Charlot—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: And by her Intereſt, to ſee his old Miſtreſs, Floriante; I know the ſtory, and what the Abbe deſigns in it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I ſhall be back in an hour; by that time the Evening will conceal you the better: If then you are brave enough—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: To meet you, with a Prieſt for a Second.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I'll have a Father ready to bleſs our endeavours.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Let him be by to ſee you play me fair,
And do your worſt or beſt, and never ſpare.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I warrant you, the firſt Night for an Heir.

div.stage: Ilford coming forward to Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O Sir, your Servant; I ſee I am beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: The moſt in the World I gad, when you know all.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Know all! I know enough to convince me, that you are not capable of a ſerious deſign of ſerving your Honour, or your Friend—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: What's the matter now, man?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And I was a Coxcomb for thinking you cou'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Nay, you may be a Coxcomb however.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What's that you ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: No quarrelling I beſeech you, till you have Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Till I have Cauſe; I think you have given me ſufficient Cauſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To thank me, I have; if you know how to be greateful.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, I muſt needs be greateful; and always confeſs the Obligation you have laid upon me, in promoting my Intereſt ſo viſibly with Volante—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: So oppoſite to my own with her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: With ſo much Diligence and good Nature—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Well remembred, I gad.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: That in my hearing, and ſtill to advance my Intereſt—you have made an Appointment to marry her—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And put you to bed to her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How, how, Sir Antony?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I knew there was no other way to do you a Service with her; therefore I reſolv'd to marry her for you, and put you to bed to her, for me.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Incomparable deſign!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A poor project of mine, Sir; if you had engag'd in't, it might ha' turn'd to account; but as 'tis, I go as I did.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But take me along with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I never impoſe a Curteſie upon any Man; nor quarrel, becauſe he is not ſenſible I am his Friend; when you come to your ſelf, you may repent—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I do repent, and confeſs my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Well; what do you confeſs your ſelf to be?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A Fool, an Aſs, to pretend to vie with you in any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And will you always keep in this humble Opinion of your ſelf, and allow me the Aſcendant?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I ſhall be an Aſs if I don't.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But you muſt confeſs your ſelf a Coxcomb—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Aye, any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: For pretending to cenſure, before you underſtood my deſign.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You told me I was a Coxcumb before; and now I begin to believe it my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Well, upon your Penitence, I pardon, and take you into favour agen.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And into the deſign.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That you muſt be: And to convince you that what I do is perfectly in your Intereſt, you ſhall marry us your ſelf—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.l: I have a Habit for you.
Thus in the World Men keep a pother,
And marry Wives for one another:
And moſt, like me, in Frolicks wooe,
And, to their ſhame, as little do;
But marry'd Women know the Senſe,
And Rights of due Benevolence:
I but provide for mine, what ſhe wou'd ſoon;
For firſt, or laſt, that Duty muſt be done.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Ilford in a Prieſt's Habit, between Sir Antony and Volante: Sir Antony leads her to the Door: Ilford dreſſes himſelf in his own Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: NOw you have done the Office of a Father to the Lady, you may do the Office of a Friend to me, and go to bed to her. I can do no more than give you an Opportunity; but if you don't employ it to her advantage, ſhe'll never rely upon you, to improve another to your own.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I never deſerve another, if I don't make uſe of this.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There's no Ceremony to make the Bride coy, in going to bed; ſhe came in an Undreſs, as looſe as her Wiſhes; and being under the impediment of but two Pins, I warrant ſhe's in Expectation already.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: She ſhant expect long.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There ſhe is; kiſs my Wife and welcome. She won't cry out, for her own ſake, till 'tis too late to diſcover it for mine.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: If ſhe ſhou'd, I think the Caſtle's our own.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I leave you to your Fortune; I am going to ſeek mine in another Adventure.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You have made my Fortune here.

div.head: SCENE Changes to a Bed-Chamber. SONG.
div.p: Methinks my Knight begins to ſhew himſelf already, in a Husbands Indifference; makeing we wait ſo long alone, in a place, where nothing but his Company can entertain me: But I have heard indeed, that ſhe who marries a Man for his converſation or good humour, takes care only to ſecure the leaſt, or the worſt part of it to her ſelf: So this is but a ſmall fault in Matrimony; and ten to one, before the Year comes about, I may have a more reaſonable cauſe of repenting. I think I hear him? O Sir, are you come?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sooner than you expected, I believe.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How! Ilford—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I ſee you are ſurpriz'd to ſee me here; and indeed the Occaſion, that brings me to you, is very ſurprizing.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What can you mean by this?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You have ſtol'n a Wedding, Madam, tho' you think to make it a ſecret; you can't expect that Sir Antony ſhou'd bring his Vanity ſo low, not to make a Boaſt of the Favour he has done you.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: By ſending you to me?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To wiſh you Joy.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: A very likely ſtory.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And give you Joy, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Wou'd Sir Antony wou'd come, to thank you for your Complement.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He ſent me with the Complement—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He ſend you!

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To ſupply his place to Night. Your Husband wo'not come.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not come to me?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Be ſatisfied ſo far, you are abus'd; and to convince you, tho' too late, how unreaſonably you have have prefer'd that Creature to every Body, he has done what no body elſe cou'd ha' done to you.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Giv'n me a fuller Revenge upon your Folly and Scorn, than I cou'd ha' conceiv'd for my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What has he done to me?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He has marry'd and undone you, left you—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Left me!

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The firſt Night left you; left you to me: Not that I believe he deſign'd me a favour, more than he wou'd ha' done any Man elſe; but you had us'd me ſo very ill, he imagin'd, I was capable of any malicious Deſign of expoſing you.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Of expoſing me!

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But that you need not apprehend from me.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I'm in your power; but pitty me. My Folly, and my Fortune are too plain.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Do you perceive it now?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I ſhou'd ha' ſeen it ſooner.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: 'Tis well you find it now. However you deſerve of me; I come to ſerve you: And ſince this opportunity (that favours, and was given me for baſer ends) encourages me to nothing, beyond the hope of your eſteem, you muſt give me leave to think, that, from my behaviour, I deſerve that Honour better than my trifling Rival does the Title of your Love.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You deſerve every thing.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I ſay enough to warn you of him; but you wou'd venture.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: My ſhame confounds me!

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You wou'd not credit me.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I can but wiſh I had.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Were it to do agen, you wou'd follow your Inclination, and do the ſame thing?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I hate the Villain.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: In your Anger?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: No, to death I hate him: And were I free from him—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You wou'd not marry him!

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Then you are free from him.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How! free from him!
