sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Not marry'd to him.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Wou'd you cou'd prove it too.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I'll make it plain, if you'll conſent to it—

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: More willingly, than I did e're conſent. Make that but plain to me; and what returns are in the poor power of one ſo loſt—

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: So ſav'd, I hope.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You ſhall command.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I may reſtore you to your liberty; but never can my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: This is the time, and place of appointment; what 'twill come to, Valentine, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis a whimſical Undertaking methinks, to ſupport another Woman's Intrigue, at your Expence—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There's no buying ſuch a Frolick to dear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And part with your Lover to oblige her!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: So long, I can't part with you; to provide for your pleaſure as well as my own: Beſides, 'tis a diverting piece of Roguery; and will be a Jeſt as long as we know one another.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Who's there? Sir Antony!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: The ſame; I am afore-hand with you.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: The Lady, Sir, will thank you. Whom have you with you there?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Only a Servant.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: You'll have no need of him; I come to ſerve you: Beſides he may be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I'll ſend him away.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: I'll but ſtep in, to make your way to the Lady, and will wait upon you agen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By this Fellow's adviſing to ſend away your Servant, I fancy he may be a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If he be a Rogue, I am reſlv'd to diſcover the bottom of him; but if there be a Woman in the caſe, I'll leave you to the Employment—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Are you alone?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Follow me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Follow me.

div.head: SCENE changes to the inſide of a Houſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your Pimp proceeds with Caution. But theſe dark Deeds may require our dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Give it me; I can manage this; you muſt manage the Lady, and for once, not to make a Cuſtom of it, I'll hold a Candle to you.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Where are you, Sir Antony?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: I'm glad you are, and here I'll keep you—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Have you forgot your Friend the Pilgrim? I am that Lady in love with you; and now I have you to my ſelf, I muſt come nearer to you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Devil you muſt—
sp.stage: Throws Palmer down, Sir Antony with his Lanthorn goes to 'em,

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Are you my Friend the Pilgrim, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Then I am loſt agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why how came I to forget you ſo ſoon? and are you the Lady that was in love with me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Riſe; and tell all you know of this buſineſs, or it ſhall be the laſt you ſhall ever engage in; I know enough of you to ſend you to the Galleys.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Why indeed Gentlemen, I won't ſtand Trial with you; I confeſs ſome deſign of my own upon Sir Antony; but your very good Friend, the Abbe, firſt ſet it on foot, by employing, and paying me well, to decoy you into his power: Now, Sir, knowing your Character, I thought nothing wou'd ſooner ſpirit you any where, than the hopes of a new Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You ſee I am true to my Aſſignation.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But where's the Abbe all this while.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: He's in the Houſe, expecting the good hour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How ſhall we do with him?

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: To make my Peace with you, I'll contribute to any Deſign againſt him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That muſt be your way.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Go then; and to keep up the Jeſt, ſay nothing of what is paſt, but bring him to me—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What do you deſign now?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To continue the Scene with him. For having, as I told you, diſpos'd of his Niece Volante to our Friend Ilſord, I ſuppoſe they may have occaſion by to morrow, for his approbation of what they are doing to night.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That's well thought on; his Conſent will come the eaſier, for our having a Hank upon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Get you gone then, like an Evidence, behind the Hangings.

div.stage: The Abbe enters to Sir Antony, ſinging, and dances round him.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Have I caught you, my little Mercury! have I caught you!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You're very nimble, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Aye, aye; I have it in my head.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: And in your heels too.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Upon occaſion— Ah my little Man! I'm young again; when I like my Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But who cou'd expect to ſee you here?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why any body wou'd have expected it: How cou'd you expect otherwiſe? How cou'd you think, I cou'd ſtay from you ſo long? What, you expected a Woman?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I did indeed.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Let the Women expect you, there's a plentiful Crop of Maidenheads; if the War continues to carry off the Whore-maſters, ſome of 'em muſt fall of themſelves, without gathering; there will ſcarce be Reapers enow for that Harveſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There's no Female-Famine, in this Year's Almanack; no fear of wanting Women.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: No, no; no fear of wanting Women: But a good natur'd, old merry Fellow, as I may be, who can tittle tattle, and goſſip in their Families, upon an ancient Privilege with the Mothers, may do any thing with the Daughters: Such a Man is a Jewel, to bring you together.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Such a Man wou'd be a Jewel indeed.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I know, you little Rogue, your buſineſs is to be wicked: I love to be wicked my ſelf too ſometimes, as often as I can decently bring it about, without ſcandal: And I will be as wicked— As wicked as I can be, for you, and with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You can do no more than you can do, good old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Old Gentleman! I won't be an old Gentleman; I'm never older than the Company I am in: What, Five and fifty does not make an old Man; 'tis want of Appetite, Infirmity, and Decay, not Five and fifty, that makes a Man old: Five and fifty has it's Pleaſures—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: As good have none, Abbe; they are faint and feeble.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Delicate and dainty, my Dear; palatable and pleaſant, and thou art mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: How ſhall I know that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why thou ſha't know, all in good time, Child; but an old Fellow, you ſay! [Unbuttons, and throws down his Cloak.] What ſhall I do now, to convince you, that I am not an old Fellow? Let me ſee; what ſhall I do for you?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: What can you do for me!

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To prove you are not an old Fellow.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: What can I?—Why I can—I can part with my Money to thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: That's one Argument indeed.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Beſides I can— I won't tell you what I can: But if you'll ſtep into the next Room with me, I have a Collation for you, and a—There you ſhall find, what I can do for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If I ſhou'd retire with you, you'll be diſappointed—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: No, no, don't talk of diſappointment; I hate to be diſappointed.—We're very luckily alone, and ſhou'd make a good uſe of our time; no body will come to diſturb us.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But I may diſappoint you my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: You will exceedingly; if you don't go a long with me: Delays are dangerous, when Opportunities are ſcarce; and we elderly Fellows have 'em but ſeldom— I vow I'll teize you, and kiſs you into good humour; I ſwear I will; if you won't go.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But 'tis not in my power to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I'll put it into your power, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But that I doubt, Sir. For very unhappily for your purpoſe; I am a—Woman.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Ha! how, a Woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: A Woman!

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: What the Devil have I been doing all this while? A Woman! Are you ſure you're a Woman?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: How ſhall I convince you?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Nay, nay; I am eaſily convinc'd; the very Name has convinc'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: But if you have a mind to be ſatisfied—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I thank you Madam, I am ſatisfied, more than I deſire to be ſatisfied; and as much ſatisfied as I can be, with a Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I told you I ſhould diſappoint you.—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: You did indeed; and you have kept your word with me, you have diſappointed me, plaguely diſappointed me. But I beg your pardon, Madam, I hope there's no offence in a little Waggery—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: None at all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: I don't uſe to take the freedom of being ſo familiar with the Ladies—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I do believe you.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Indeed I don't; I pay a greater Reſpect to your Sex: And had I known you were a Woman before, I had kept my diſtance—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Sir, Ceremony among Friends! Tho' you know me now to be a Woman, you need not keep a diſtance. What tho' I have diſappointed you in your way, I may make you amends in my own—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: So you may indeed, Madam—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You gueſs what I mean, Abbe?

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: If you wou'd be but ſo gracious.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: How gracious wou'd you have me be?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Ah! you'll never grant me the favour—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: What favour?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why— to ſay nothing of this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Is that the favour?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: That's all, Madam? the greateſt favour you can do me; and then you do my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Can you part with any Money now to me, now I'm a Woman?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Here are a hundred Luidores in this Purſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To muzzle the Scandal.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: And I'll get you a Husband into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She'll keep your Council, Abbe.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Hem, hem, hem!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And in the ſcarcity of Men, you'll do her a mighty favour, I can tell her, to ſecure a Husband for her.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Hold you your Tongue, Sir. You ſhall have a Wife too, if Floriante will content you; that Rogue Palmer has betray'd me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No body ſhall betray you; we are all Friends: But this Lady and I have a favour to beg of you.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: A favour to beg of me! Any thing, any thing, as many favours as you pleaſe; 'tis but asking, and having, in the humour I am in, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Our Friend, Ilford, has marry'd your Niece Volante, and you muſt give your Conſent to the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Give my Conſent to the Wedding! Why, I'll dance at the Wedding. I'll have a Fiddle, and a young Fellow to tickle me, and teach me to Caper. Gads ſo; I don't know what Legs I ſtand upon at the news on't! I'll be as brisk as the Bridegroom the firſt Night. But we ſhall neither of us hold it; twon't laſt the Year round with us; I'm an old Fellow, that's the truth on't, 'tis done with me already; I'm upon my laſt Legs. But I have Floriante and Charlot to provide for ſtill; Poor Girls! while they are in a Nunnery, they lie upon my Conſcience: let me but bring them into the World agen, and I'll be contented to go out on't—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not yet a great while, Abbe.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: As ſoon as I can get my ſelf in the mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Wee'l keep you in another mind.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Nay, I am eaſily perſwaded; but I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Lady Abbeſs is conſenting to their Eſcape.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Being a Kinſwoman, ſhe was eaſily perſwaded to give 'em an Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis near the time now; wou'd I had Ilford here.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why, I am here; I'll ſtand and fall by you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I muſt not now expoſe you.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: If you can but carry 'em off, the buſineſs is laid to your hands.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: My buſineſs is over in this Town; and I had beſt get off while I can; for fear of bringing a worſe buſineſs upon me.

div.head: SCENE, the back-ſide of a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What Floriante means by this Invitation to me, I can't tell; 'tis a favour ſhe never vouchſafed me before: Perhaps the apprehenſion of taking the Habit which her Father intends ſhe ſhall, has wrought upon her to conſent rather to marry me: But let her conſent, and deſign what ſhe pleaſe, if ſhe puts her ſelf into my power, as to Night ſhe ſays ſhe will, I deſign to let her ſee, how very little I value that favour, for which I muſt be oblig'd more to her Confinement, then to her Inclination, or Choice. Stand cloſe, here's Company.

div.stage: Enter Valentine, Sir Antony, and two Servants.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am as full of apprehenſion, as an old Soldier upon the Guard of a Counterſcarp; where his Fears cannot be more uneaſie, than my Hopes are now.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: He ſhou'd be an Engliſhman, by the Similitude, to let his Friends know, from his own mouth, that he has made a Campagne.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: This is the backſide of the Nunnery—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And the Garden Door— I think I hear it open—
O Floriante!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Stand faſt, we're ſet upon.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You muſt not meet the danger—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Fall on, and kill the Raviſher—
Come, my fair Fugitive, you muſt along with me.

div.stage: Valentine's Party beats the Bravo's off; one wounded ſtays. Floriante Enters as Charlot did.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: What noiſe was that?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Some help, I hope.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: How my Siſter Charlot has ſucceeded, under my Name, with her Count, to morrow will diſcover.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ha! the Count then has the wrong Woman.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Wou'd Valentine were come.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: O wou'd he were to help me!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Who's there? a Man wounded?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: One of your Servants; if you are Floriante.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: And wounded in your Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for't; do you belong to Valentine?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: He got off ſafe; and if you'll lend me your charitable hand, I'll guide you to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Rogues, Sons of Whores, and Cowards!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Here am I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I was afraid I had loſt you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Here's an honeſt man was conducting me to you, one of your Friends.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: One of my Friends! He's one I did not reckon upon, if he be— This is one of Count Verole's Bravo's.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I am; and had not you interrupted me, I had done my Maſter ſervice; carry'd the Lady to him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: What a Miſchief have I ſcap'd—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thou art a gallant Fellow, and doſt deſerve a better Maſter; but thou haſt done thy duty, and I will do mine; carry him home, and get a Surgeon to him—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Well; I run a mighty venture.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Of looſing a Maiden-head, I grant you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I may Repent—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: The keeping of it ſo long.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I may repent at leiſure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You may indeed, if you don't make haſte; for we muſt expect to be purſu'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You and I, Madam, are much about a ſize; what if we change Cloaths; it may favour your Eſcape, if you come to be follow'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Admirably thought on! Madam, you need not make a ſcruple of ſhifting before Sir Antony; whom, from this time, you may know to be a Woman.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: A Woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Now for my Petticoats agen—

div.head: SCENE, the Abbe's Houſe.
div.stage: Count Canaile, Count Verole, Abbe and Charlot.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt thank you for the care you have ſhewn of my Family; tho' I believe it has carry'd you farther then you are aware off: This is my Daughter Charlot.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: The very ſame. But Floriante is oblig'd to you; you meant this favour to her: But by this time, ſhe has put her ſelf into the care of a Gentleman, who will find a kinder away of diſpoſing her, then into the hands of her Father.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Diſhonourable Girl!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: If it be poſſible, I'll recover her, and yet revenge my Love.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: But Charlot, how came you to think of running away with Valentine, when you know I deſign'd you to marry him?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Why, I thank you, Sir, you deſign'd very well for me; But I was too well acquainted with Valentine, and my Siſter's thoughts, to depend over
much upon that hope: I knew there was no parting them; therefore conſented the eaſier to aſſiſt her, in getting out of the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Very well Brother!

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Let her go on.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I began to apprehend the danger of ſtaying behind in a place, and profeſſion, wholly diſagreeable to my humour.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: And well you might.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I thought fit to provide for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: In good time you did, Niece.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And accordingly, in my Siſter's name, I ſent to Count Verole; he came at the time appointed, expecting Floriante: But Valentine, by what accident, I know not, coming before his time, knowing nothing of me, or my Plot upon the Count, took me for her, call'd me Floriante, upon which his Bravo's fell upon Valentine: But the Count in a more gentle-manly regard to his Perſon, encountred me, and brought me where you find me.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: But methinks the Count, taking you for Floriante, his old Miſtreſs, might ha' made another uſe of his Victory, then to have brought you in triumph to your Father.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I expected he wou'd indeed; but by what he ſaid to me, I found he had little or no deſign in coming there; but to revenge himſelf upon my Siſter, and her ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I'm glad he has no other deſign upon her.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And ſo am I indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why Charlot? You are not in Love with the Count?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Not ſo much in love with the Count, as I am out of love with a Nunnery: Any man had been as welcome.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Well, well; if Valentine be not hurt, this matter will clear of it ſelf—

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: And ſo it will, I warrant you.

div.head: SCENE, the Street.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Why, how a Man may be miſtaken in his Friends! I cou'd not ha' believ'd it; (had not one of their underling Rogues told me ſo himſelf) that any one cou'd ha' been ſo cheated, as I have been, by my own Countrymen— If I durſt but ſend any of 'em a Challenge, I might get ſome of my money agen; but that may draw me into a worſe Premunire, then I have yet been in. Let me ſee; Can't I have a ſafer Revenge upon 'em? Valentine has ſtoll'n a Fortune, and entruſted me to bring a Father to marry em; now if I ſhould go wilfully, in a miſtake, to the Gentlewoman's own Father, for a Licence to marry 'em. The truth on't is, I have a mind to forbid the Banes, and get her my ſelf, if I can; for Floriante is a Woman of Quality—

div.stage: Count Verole in purſuit of her, Enters with his Bravo's.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Do you know her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Yes. Sir, I think I do.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Then as you are a Gentleman, aſſiſt me; thus far I have News of her.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p:
I am a Gentleman, Sir; you ſhall find me a Gentleman: And I'll tell you more News of her; I'll carry you to the very place, where ſhe
is, Sir; and that's as much as you can expect from a Gentleman, when a Friend is concern'd.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: It is indeed, Sir, more then I expected; pray along with me.
Valentine with Floriante in Sir Antony's, and Sir Antony in her Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: So far we are ſafe, Ladies, and the ſhifting your Habits will ſecure us ſo: Wou'd Sir Gentle wou'd come agen; you're grave at the thought of him!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Men of your Converſation and Experience in the World, Valentine, ſeldom like the Women you marry.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Becauſe we ſeldom marry the Women we like.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Well, ſince Marriage at beſt is a Venture, I had as good make it my ſelf, as let another make it for me, at my Coſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To let a Father chooſe for you in Love, is as unlucky, as when you are in fancy at play, and puſhing at a Sum, to deſire another to throw out your hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if that fool Sir Gentle has not betray'd us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yonder he comes indeed, with a Rabble of Rogues at his heels.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: There's no reſiſting 'em; provide for your ſelves as well as you can.
I have yet a Trick to cozen 'em.

div.stage: Enter Sir Gentle and Verole, as before.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: See, ſee, upon ſight of us, they have quitted their Prize: Is this their Engliſh Gallantry? They're out of ſight already. Let 'em go; the Lady is our Game.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I'll make ſome of 'em know to their Coſt, that by uſing me ſo little like a Gentleman, they have taught me to do as I do, and uſe 'em as they deſerve.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Now Floriante, you find you have thrown your ſelf a way, upon a Fellow that has not the ſpirit to ſtand by you, or himſelf, to keep your Folly in countenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Pray Sir, a word with you—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Well Madam: What can you ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Why, I ſay, you're an Aſs to run about to diſturb other People: I am Sir Antony Love, not Floriante; don't diſcover me for your own ſake; but get you gone about your buſineſs, and leave me to this Engliſh man.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I'll take his Advice, for fear of being laugh'd at: Sir, you have behav'd your ſelf ſo like a Man of Honour in this buſineſs, that I muſt deſire you to take care of the Lady, while I go to inform her Father of what has happen'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I'll take care of her, I warrant you. Why, what a lucky Rogue am I! upon my firſt inclination to play the Knave, to have ſo good an occaſion of doing it.
And indeed, who wou'd take a truſt upon him, but for the privledge and benefit of breaking it?—So Madam, now I have you in my Care.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You are a civil Gentleman, I know you.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: You ſhall know me for a civil Gentleman, if you pleaſe; tho I am a Knight, where I am not familiar.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: I know you are, Sir; you may have pity for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Alack a day! I have indeed, a heart brim-full for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: You won't force me to marry that Monſter?

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Not I, as I hope to be ſav'd, Madam; nothing againſt fancy.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: To throw away my Youth, Beauty, and Fortune, which you know are not contemptible.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Incomparable, Madam; incomparable; your Youth and Beauty, without your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Wou'd they were worth your asking.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Wou'd I might have 'em for asking.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: Valantine I deſpair of; but if there be an Enliſh-man, as an Engliſh-man he muſt be—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Why, I am an Engliſh-man; and wou'd marry you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: The ſooner you ſecure me, the better then.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I think ſo too, Madam.

div.stage: Canaile, Verole, Abbe, Ilford, Volante, Charlott, Enter.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Why here's a Night of Action indeed; Ilford, you began the Dance with Volante; and Count, I hope you'll continue it, with my Niece Charlot: As for Valentine and Floriante, they have had their frisk in a corner by this time, or he is not the Man I take him for.

sp.speaker: Verol.
sp.p: When you fell into my hands to Night; had I known my good Fortune, I had improv'd it then: But now I have it, in having you—And happier yet, in having your Conſent.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: You have my Bleſſing both—

div.stage: Valentine and Floriante at the Door.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: You may appear, we're all of a Family now, Cozen Germans, and Friends— Come here's a Pair that wants your Bleſſing too.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I can't deny it now— Riſe and be happy.

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: I have a Bleſſing too for you, my Girls; Five thouſand Crowns a piece more than I deſign'd you; and a Thouſand extraordinary for her who brings me the firſt Boy; a ſmall Gratuity, Gentlemen, to keep up your Fancy, and encourage your pains, that you mayn't think it unprofitable Labour upon your Wives.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: But why in Sir Antony's Cloaths, Floriante? Where is this mad Knight?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Somewhere in my Petticoats: But the Count can give you the beſt Tidings of him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I left him with one Sir Gentle Golding; one whom you are beholden to; for familiarly, upon the firſt word, he betray'd you, and carry'd me to ſeize you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, I don't doubt but ſhe will give us a handſom Revenge upon him.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: She? Who?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir Antony, Sir; For this Sir Antony after all, is a Woman.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A Woman!

sp.speaker: Abbe.
sp.p: Aye, pox take her, ſhe is a Woman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Then I am free indeed.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And I am happy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: At leiſure I'll tell you all her ſtory.

div.stage: Ente Sir Gentle with Sir Antony.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p:
Now, I am ſufficiently reveng'd on Valentine and Sir Antony for
cheating me; I think I have paid 'em in their own Coin: And diſappointed the Count too, in marrying Floriante.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Come Father-in-Law, this buſineſs will out I ſee; if you'll give us your bleſſing, ſo; if not, I ſhall begin upon your Daughter without ſaying Grace.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Much good may do you, Sir, with your Bride.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Aye, aye; we muſt all wiſh you Joy, Sir; You have a Bleſſing ſufficient in a good Wife—

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.p: If you know when you're well.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: O deliver me! What do I ſee!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why you ſee your old Mrs. Lucy, in your new Lady-wife; we are all Witneſſes of your owning your marriage.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: I do not own it— I'll hang like a Dog, drown like a blind Puppy, die and be damn'd, but I'll be divorc'd from her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That's your neareſt way to Divorce.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And will ſave the trouble of Doctor's Commons.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come, come, I'll put you in a better; There are old Scores between you and Mrs. Lucy— You have made her a Lady indeed, which ſhews a grateful Nature in you, and will ſound well in the Ears of the World. But to ſupport her Quality—

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Her Qualities will ſupport that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Out of your Two thouſand pounds a Year, give her a Rent-charge of Five hundred, and ſhe ſhall never trouble you more, not ſo much as to be a Godfather to another Man's Child upon her Body, which may otherwiſe inherit your Acres.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.p: Why there's the Devil on't agen, to Father another man's Children, when one is not ſo much as a-kin to 'em! Well, any Compoſition to be rid of her; I find 'tis a Bleſſing I muſt pay for.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come, come, we muſt have a Dance to all theſe Weddings.

sp.speaker: Sir Ant.
sp.l: Thus Coxcombs always the beſt Husbands prove;
When we are faulty, and begin to rove,
A ſep'rate Maintenance ſupplies our Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Gent.
sp.l: When we have Miſtreſſes above our Senſe,
We muſt redeem our Perſons with our Pence.

div.head: A SONG in the Second ACT.

lg.l: PUrſuing Beauty, Men deſcry
The diſtant Shore, and long to prove
(Still richer in Variety)
The Treaſures of the Land of Love.
We Women, like weak Indians, ſtand
Inviting, from our Golden Coaſt,
The wandring Rovers to our Land:
But ſhe, who Trades with 'em, is loſt.
With humble Vows they firſt begin,
Stealing, unſeen, into the Heart:
But by Poſſeſſion ſetled in,
They quickly act another part.
For Beads, and Baubles, we reſign,
In Ignorance, our ſhining Store.
Diſcover Nature's richeſt Mine,
And yet the Tyrants will have more.
Be wiſe, be wiſe, and do not try,
How he can Court, or you be Won:
For Love is but Diſcovery,
When that is made, the Pleaſure's done.

div.head: A SONG in Dialogue, in the Fourth ACT.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: NO more, Sir, no more, I'll ev'n give it o're
I ſee it is all but a Cheat;
Your ſoft wiſhing Eyes, your Vows, and your Lies,
Which thus ſo you often repeat.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis you are to blame, who fooliſhly claim
So ſilly a lean Sacrifice:
But Lovers, who pray, muſt always obey,
And bring down their Knees, and their Eyes.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: Of late you have made, Devotion a Trade
In Loving, as well as Religion:
But you cannot prove, thro' th' Ages of Love,
any Worſhip was offer'd but One.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That one let it be, in which we agree,
Leave Forms to the Maids, who are younger:
We're both of a mind, make haſt, and be kind,
And continue a Goddeſs no longer.

div.head: SONG in the Fifth ACT. By Major-General Sackvile.

lg.l: IN vain Clemene you beſtow
The promis'd Empire of your Heart,
If you refuſe to let me know
The wealthy Charms of every part.
My Paſſion with your Kindneſs grew,
Tho' Beauty gave the firſt deſire:
But Beauty only to purſue,
Is following a wandring Fire.
As Hills in Perſpective ſuppreſs
The free Enquiry of the Sight:
Reſtraint makes every Pleaſure leſs,
And takes from Love the full delight.
Faint Kiſſes may in part ſupply
Thoſe eager Longings of my Soul;
But oh! I'm loſt, if you deny
A quick poſſeſſion of the whole.

div.head: PROLOGUE. Spoken by Mrs. Bracegirdle.
div.l: THE Ladies have a lonely Summer paſt,
In hopes kind Winter would return at laſt.
The Seaſons change; but Heroes at the ſame,
A Twelve-month running in purſuit of Fame.
Theirs may be good, but they have ſpoilt our Game.
Some weak amends this thin Town might afford,
If honeſt Gentlemen would keep their word.
But your lewd Tunbridge-Scandal that was moving,
Foretold how ſad a Time wou'd come for Loving.
Sad Time indeed when you begin to write:
'Tis a ſhrewd ſign of wanting Appetite,
When you forget your ſelves, to think of Wit.
Whilſt thus your Itch is only to beſpatter,
Your Cupid is transform'd into a Satyr:
Nothing of Man about you, all o're Beaſt;
Submitting your chief pleaſure to your Jeſt.
Then Time will come (for Ireland falls of Courſe,
And muſt ſend back her Conquerours, and ours)
When each of us our Loſſes do recover,
Will mend her Fortune in a Soldier-Lover:
They'l uſe us better much, then you have done,
Take us in, paſſing, like an open Town,
And plunder, do their buſineſs, and be gone.
Or if, at leiſure, they lye down to wooe,
They'l rather make us Whores, then call us ſo:
Not ſend a whiſp'ring Libel thro' the Town,
To blab the Favour out, before 'tis done;
And maul the Ladies only in Lampoon.
But if they write in a Sententious Strain,
Two Lines conclude the Travels of their Pen;
One, only to know where, and t'other, when.
And we can give a Lover leave to write,
When all his Bills are to be paid at ſight.
O! wou'd our peaceful days were come agen;
Then I might act it, on and off, a Queen.
When once the Child was turn'd into her Teens,
You cou'd not find a Maid behind the Scenes.
But now your keeping humor's out a door,
We muſt dye Maids, or marry to be poor.

div.head: EPILOGUE. Spoken by Mrs. Botelar.
div.l: IF Novelty has any Charms to move,
We hope, to Night, we've rais'd your drooping Love:
Not to the Youngſters of a noiſy Pit,
Whoſe Tongues and Miſtreſſes out-run their Wit:
But to the graver Sinners of the Bench.
Who, from your Mothers Maids, have lov'd a Wench:
Who, cheek by joul with Time, have handled down
The Vices of all Ages to your own:
Here's a Variety, that may delight
The Palate of each Ages Appetite.
To you I'm ſent, you who have dearly known
The ſeveral Rates of Pleaſure in this Town;
And find at laſt, 'tis worth but your Half-Crown.
You'l hear with Patience a dull Scene, to ſee,
In a contented lazy waggery,
The Female Montford bare above the knee.
She makes a mighty noiſe, like ſome of you,
Who often talk of what you never do:
She's for all Womankind, and aws the Town,
As if her Husband's Breeches were her own.
She's been to Night our Hero, tho' a Female,
Show me but ſuch a Whoremaſter, tho' a Male
Who thro' ſo many ſhifts, is ſtill the ſame,
Purſues all Petticoats, preſerves her Fame,
And tho' ſhe can do nothing, keeps the Name.
Some of your Names are up too we ſuppoſe,
Who turn'd of fifty, ſtill wou'd paſs for Beau's:
You dance, you dreſs, you ſing, you keep a noiſe,
And think you're young, becauſe you herd with Boys.
To ſuch as you, there is no Mercy owing;
Your talking muſt not ſerve for your not doing.
And ſince your feeble failings within doors
Are known to us, be wiſe, and even Scores;
Supply our Wants, and we'll conceal all yours.
No matter what you can, or cannot do,
You ſhall cheat others ſtill, if we cheat you:
Keep us but rich, and fine, and we ſhall find
Young Lovers, always able to be kind.
